div.head: To the Honourable and most Accomplished Lady YATE, of Harvington in Worcestershire.
div.p:
SInce the most weak, ought to endeavour the most powerful Defenders; I could no where elect a person whose Accomplishments renders them so capable to that requisite, as your Ladyship: Which Motive I onely have to hope and plead my Pardon by, for my Presumption in imploring your Protection.
Madam, This earthy effect of my ignorant Brain, you will find an Engin, which will give all your Perfections and Virtues employment in the most eminent degree; since it not only requires your unequal'd Eloquence and Wisdom, to appose the Censuring world, upon this uncommon action in my Sex: but your Goodness to pardon the many and high defects, which you will there find to condemn.

Sinners look not upon their own weak merits, but Heavens Bounty, when they implore Benefits: For if they should turn their Eyes to their inward View, and regulate their Petitions by their Deservings; they would blush and grow dumb to all Requests. This Line, Madam, I must draw to my own Center; who must wholly ow all your transcending Favours, to your generous aud noble Humour, which makes the World your Admirers, and fixes unalterably to the power of your Commands,

closer.signed: Your most humble Servant and Kinswoman, F. Boothby.

div.head: PROLOGUE TO Marcelia.
div.l: I'M hither come, but what d'ye think to say?
A Womans Pen presents you with a Play:
Who smiling told me I'd be sure to see,
That once confirm'd, the House wou'd empty be.
Not one yet gone!—
Well, I'l go tell her you are all so just,
You'l laugh at her on Knowledg, not on Trust.
I know she'l send me back, but what to do,
When I have learn'd of her, I'l tell it you.
Guess now the Message: she prays ye to be gone,
You'l croud her Wit to death in such a Throng
Of Wits, she says, which no Consumptions have,
And hers is weak, e'en going to the grave.
She wonders much that ye should all desire
To stay, and witness when it does expire.
Mess. Hark ye the Poetess does angry grow.
Prol. I cannot make'em whether they will or no.
'Tis better be a Dog, than Womans slave,
That knows not what she would, or would not have.
With Ballading I think she mad is grown,
And by her Prologue fain would make it known.
She need not be so hasty; faith her Play
Will witness that her Reason's gone astray:
For when that it is done, I'm almost sure,
You'l give her Bedlam for Reward or Cure.
What more? nay then I never shall have done;
Now I've command to court ye one by one:
When I return to send her word by me,
Who will her Judges, who her Lawyers be.
If that the Wits will plead her cause, she'l stay;
If not, she fairly means to run away:
For if her Judges they resolve to sit,
She neither Pardon nor Reprieve shall get.
But still she hopes the Ladies out of Pride
And Honor, will not quit their sexes side:
Though they in private do her faults reprove,
They'l neither publick scorn nor laughter move.
But should they all in censuring be severe,
'Tis still the Critick Men she most does fear:
For if that Solomon now liv'd, and writ;
They'd cry, Pish, hang't, there's nothing in't of Wit..

div.head: The ACTORS Names.

list.item: Lotharicus A noble man, in love with Marcelia.
Euryalus, A noble man, Sister to Marcelia.
Moriphanus, a proud, silly, rich fellow.
Marcelia, a noble Lady, Consin to Melinet.

div.p: Pages, Foot-Boys, Maskers, Guards and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: HAve you seen Melinet of late?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, not since he miss'd the place he thought himself so sure of at the Court; his aspiring soul will not easily let him digest the cross events of Fate.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: It seems a marvel to me he had it not, for the King does reflect upon him more than common rays of favour; such, as in my mind may reasonably give his hopes large compass.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ho does so, but this was a grant of our deceased King, which his Majesty promised to ratifie; or else doubtless he had carried it: but men of his temper, and nobly born, without Estates, think Fortune is a cripple, if she does not with winged hast answer their deserts.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Hold, here he is coming, with a musing and unsatisfied countenance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How now, Melynet, what, dull and melancholy?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: My looks, my Lord, wear my fortunes livery:
But I was just now thinking how many considerable
Places I have been likely to possess;
And my stars, my unlucky stars,
They still prevent me with their baser influences.
Oh I could curse them! had they made me a fool,
Or without Spirit or Ambition:
I should have thankd 'em; but they 've furnish'd me
With all the requisites to a rising Fortune,
And yet deny success.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I' faith, the truth of 'tis, they have afforded thee
Wit, subtilty, policie, and what else is necessary,
Enough to have discharg'd any office in the Kingdom,
To thy own advantage; and that's now the onely end
To which most of the greatest Statesmen tend.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I, for they are wiser than in the old time,
When Honour and Honesty were so much ador'd:
They of that age were altogether in love with Fame,
And having their lives read with admiration in a chronicle.
But the Politicians now are of another stamp:
What's present's only theirs, they cry; and had rather
Purchase one life here in a good estate,
Than the inheritance of that talk'd of,
That is to come hereafter. 'Tis true,
Expectation is a hungry Diet.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: You would think so, if your Lordship were to live Upon it as many do.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I should so, but not in thy condition,
Who art already look'd upon by every man of judgment,
As in all likelihood to be the Court Blazing-star.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: That expression will bear a various interpretation:
Or great, or mischievous, or both: perhaps
By divination he gives it for my Motto.
Well, I beg your Lordships pardon, for I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why, pry ' thee, what hast of business
Calls you away?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I am engag'd to meet six or seven Friends.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No friends, as you love me: a Friend is a thing
More rare than a Phoenix, and thou talk'st of them,
As if they were as common as Fishes
And did like them increase and multiply.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Well, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I wonder whether the King still intends the
Marriage of Calinda: there are many
Wagers in the town about it.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: O! Monarchs and Subjects are two different things▪
And a sudden rise to eminent Honour or Fortune,
Commonly proves like the Turks Mutes to an old
Affection; strangle in quite: and 'tis whisper'd
By the most knowing. that the Kings Love has at present
the cold fit of an aguish distemper on it, to that Lady.
But well, are you for my company this afternoon, or not?
For I am design'd to go home: I am promis'd the sight of
A fellow that will needs be thought a Lord:
They say he'l make a man dy with laughing.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Then I'm resolv'd not to see him to day:
For I have a great mind to live ill to morrow,
And for this afternoon I'll throw it away
Amongst the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: Let not your grief take yet such full possession
Of your heart, till more of time gives the assurance
Of what is onely now your passions fear.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Alas Ericina! it is that uncertainty
Which makes Loves greatest Hell: were I but once
Assur'd, I should be less concern'd.
But whilst I doubt I nothing can resolve:
Reason and scorn, which then would prove my cure▪
I am now by that unhappy motive (that you urge
To lessen my affections) forbid their use:
For 'tis not his new acquired greatness
Can keep my heart in slavery. It was
His Noble Mind I lov'd. And that the greatest
Ebb of Fortune could ne'er have given change to.
Indeed I did adore his virtues, and made
Him Soveraign of my heart, despising in
My thoughts for him, all those that onely could
Pretend advantages in Wealth, which possibly
They did inherit by their Fathers crimes.
But if I find he is turn'd Apostate
To what gave being to my Passion:
I shall depose him here, to let him see
His Honour lost, his Crowns despis'd by me.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: If the assurance of his unconstancie
Will prove so much less afflicting than the fear,
Force your belief to that Conclusion,
His actions afford enough of cause.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ah! Ericina, thou then dost think him chang'd.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: It ill would suit the Friendship I profess,
Still by dissembling my thoughts to his advantage,
To help to shipwrack so your quiet,
Urging the Uncertainty of what,
I must confess I do no longer doubt.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Nor I no longer that I'm quite undone!

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: And I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Oh hold, Ericina;
Keep to thy self those thoughts, which if set free,
With furious floods of grief would deluge me.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: Can you believe your ruine I design?
Whose life is dearer to me far than mine.
No, Calinda, what I have done was only but to try,
Whether the Cure your Reason did propose,
Your Courage could endure the application of.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How could your pity let you make experiments,
On my Misfortune to improve your knowledg?
Or what of satisfaction do you find
From the assurance that my tongue had boasted,
Without consulting of my heart, the resolution
Of that indifferencie and change, if he
Prove false, my soul can never find for him.
You us'd to take so great an interest in
My sufferings as made their weight seem less.
But you unkindly now do seek to multiply my griess,
and they already overpress my Mind.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: My love can easily forgive the highest
Injuries with which you charge my innocence:
For, I perceive, the disquiet of your thoughts dethrones
Your Reason. But 'tis hard to be Physician,
Where the Disease admits such alteration,
As makes the Remedie uncertain.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Madam, my Lord Valasco, with some Ladies,
Are come to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Go, let them know I'll attend them.
How ill does Conversation suit my mind,
Who can in nothing, now, contentment find!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: This Kingdom has known strange and wonderful
Changes since my absence▪ for who wo'd e'er ha' thought
Sigismond should have come to be our Soveraign?
Heaven having given so many just Pretenders
To th' Grown, before his Right could put in claim.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: 'Tis true, Peregrine, but Fortunes children
Are always heirs to what she pleases.
And all his actions both in Peace and War,
Have still been crown'd with such success and glory,
As made him justly thought one of her Darling sons.
And though there are many whose wants in worth,
And height of Envy, made them strive to clip
His Honours wings: yet I must needs confess,
I think he merits what he wears.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I doubt not your Opinion; but with what
A kind of temper did he at first demean
Himself in his new Soveraignty?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: With such a Moderation as shew'd he thought
The weighty troubles that do attend the Crown
Of a well governing Prince, would far exceed
The pleasure of an expected Power and Greatness.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Yet we see those cares which Crowns create,
Are burthens, which all the great ones of the world
Do strive to carry; to which when right of birth
Is wanting, they make usurping Power, and
Treasons guilt become their unresisted title.
And certainly, what is so often purchased
By th' death of Millions, and the height of Crimes,
When lawfully acquir'd, may well excuse
A more than common joy exprest in such
An elevated Fortune.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: No doubt it does; and 'twas the general expectation, and our surprize the greater, finding his looks And actions shew such an unmov'd indifferencie.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That might beget amazement, for sudden satisfaction or high cares seldom or never keep within those bounds, Reason or policie prescribes them. But he resolv'd to shew by something far from common in Mankind, Fortune was Just, not blind, in giving him a Sceptre. But who amongst all the Court is likely to carry The name of Favorite?

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: He that possesses the greatest share is Melynet, Nephew to the late Lord Euryalus, that was the fair Marcelia's Father. His growth in greatness was like a Mushrom, so suddain, which has begot much wonder in the Court.
sp.l: Oh Lucidore!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay hold, no quarreling; I have been suffering Sufficiently for my breach of promise.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Why pr'ythee? what Disaster, that the knowledg may make some satisfaction?
For I dare swear it is some Comical accident.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If to lose a Mans Reason first, and then all his Money, be matter of Mirth; it is so: for that's the true character of my condition.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Why, just as I left you the other night, I met with our new Favourite; and straight my brain was seiz'd with a piece of policy, to try if I could drink away his Understanding, and keep so much of my own to play the Justice of Peace with him, and sift out the Reason of his so much admir'd greatness with the King: but I, like other Statesmen, fail'd in my Design, and made my self as uncapable of Questions, as he was of Answers. But that which makes me the most mad, and will make thee the most merry, was,
that I must needs be shaking of my Elbow, and pay the first Tribute to his fortune and succes in Gaming.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Why, you could do no less in complement, than since you would learn him to play, to teach him at your own costs and charges. But now confess, what did you lose?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Enough t'have purchas'd half his patrimony,
When he came to Court: a thousand pound,
And something more.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: He plays deep for a new Gamester, but he thinks With reason, his Fortune's like to have no bottom.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: I pity thy condition, for I know thy losses
Would have made thee merry a month together,
In ways much more agreable to thy humor.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: It would so; but 'tis gone, and the Devil go with it: The wish is no Treason I hope, for he was never yet, to my knowledg prohibited a Favorites company.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: If he were, they would divide the soul of their usual preferment from the bodily.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: I, for give him his due, he's a sociable Fellow, and infinitely esteem'd by all persons of all conditions, the Clergy, Statesman, the Lawyer, the Citizen, poor and rich, all strive for his Friendship, his Counsel, his Assistance; there is such pulling and halling who shall have him, that 'tis well he can be here, and there, and every-where.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That's no part of my Faith; for he has often fail'd me in business of no small concernment to his service, and my satisfaction: and yet I am certain he has not had a more faithful Friend in all the world than I have been, take one time with another.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: That I'l witness for thee is a truth, and therefore
He can't be excus'd of ingratitude, if he
Gives thee any reason of complaint.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I know not the Design, but I am confident
He will send me to heaven whether I will or no.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: If he does, thou wilt be the first Saint,
That ever came there of the Devils making.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If I am, as sure as thou livest, he does intend that wonder; well, farewell.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.l: Nay, we'l all go together.

div.head: Scene 4. Enter Sigismund and Melynet, and a Guard at distance. Attendants.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Sir, I perceive something does discompose
The quiet of your mind, and would it not
Appear too bold presumption in a Subject,
I would most humbly beg the cause.

sp.speaker: Sig.
sp.l: Melynet, your judgment makes a true interpretation, and 'tis only from thy Love and Interest that I can hope a change.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Your Majesties high bounty that rais'd me from that nothing which I was in fortune to what I am, by the so envy'd glory of your favour; besides the duty which I ow you as my Soveraign, doubly commands my life to be a ready Sacrifice on all occasions, where that offering can purchase you the least of satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Sig.
sp.p: Thou art my Friend, what name commands a greater Distance I'l forget; but what I now shall try thy kindness in, Requires more thy wit and judgment use, Than dangers hazard. You have a Kinswoman,

sp.speaker: Melinet,
sp.l: whom I have found too fair, and fear
That I shall find as cruel: it is Marcelia, I wear
Her chains, yet not without attempting to have
Broke them; but I perceive resistance is in vain.
The more I strive, the faster I am ty'd.
Nothing but Death her Fetters can divide.
But why standst thou so surpriz'd, as if thou didst
Rival me in my passion?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I wish I did Sir, so that there were no other;
But what concern I shew comes from my fear'd defect
Of power, not will, to serve your Majesties Commands.

sp.speaker: Sig.
sp.l: I do believe thee, and I know
The interposing Difficulty that stands
Between me and my hopes; a pre-engagement
Of her heart to brave Lotharicus: but may not
A King and Crown laid prostrate at her feet,
Tempt her Ambition to command her love?
Has she put off so much her Sexes frailty,
That such a Present cannot shake her constancie?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: She has often in my hearing given him that
Assurance, Sir, and though words are but airy
Sounds, till the temptation proves their substance:
Yet I have so much knowledge of her humor,
As makes me fear they shall not want that seal.
But all that my power can act in her perswasion, Sir,
To move her to a sense of that high glory,
I will give your Majesty the assurance of in some few days.

sp.speaker: Sig.
sp.l: Go my dear Melinet and sound her thoughts;

l.hi: For thou wilt in her answer to me bring,
The happiness or ruine of thy King.

sp.l: Oh mighty Love! whose power is not limited
More in a Prince than Slave! how dost thou force
My heart to turn a Rebel to my virtue!
Making my passion master of my honor,
My Reason of no farther use than no condemn the crime
I act in giving to another that heart,
Which I so often vow'd to my Calinda!
Thus in my soul I find a civil war;

l.hi: But Love o'er Virtue has the vict'ry far:
For whosoe'er does see Marceliaes eyes,
Must break their faith, and fall her sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Sirrah, I would fain know why you should pay me less respect than Beggars do? they can say, My Lord, and your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Gra.
sp.p: Because I know you better to be no Gentleman. [aside But if I must say, an' please your Lordship, what shall I say to make your Lordships honorable title pass for currant, if it should be questioned?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What shouldst thou say? say I am an outlandish Lord. Well, a man of ambitious thoughts had better be hang'd, than keep a fellow that cannot make a lie.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Good my Lord pardon me, I shall have one presently; but my Lord, you have not the mien nor breeding of a Lord: I think I had best say you are a sprout of one of those English Lords of Nol's new creation in the old Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I' faith Graculus 'twill do rarely well.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: But my Lord, since you are resolv'd upon so much greatness, you must needs enlarge your retinue.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: So I will, Graculus, and I will keep them all in several Liveries.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: They will be taken for other mens Servants then.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, no, thou art a fool; they will be all known 〈◊〉 be my men, and only wearing the several Liveries of those several Families that have match'd into my house.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: What a most excellent fancy was this! some of the chief Liveries, I hope Master. (I cry your Lordship mercy) shall be black and green, orange tawny and red, and black and deep blew.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Excellent well! thou hast a rare conceit in the choise of colors; but pr'ythee let my own suit be trim'd with the black and deep blew.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: 'Tis ten to one but your cowardly carkas may be trim'd with black and blew before you leave the town.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I have one thing more to tell thee of; I'l leave the taking of my boys to thee: but be sure thou dost instruct them, that as they follow me, ever as I turn my head (as I shall do very often) that they all stand still and put off their hats, for it is a great point of breeding in all Foot-boys, and of state in Masters. And go to my Taylor, and bid him make hast with my cloaths, and let every thing that is in the Mode be doubled upon them.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: I shall, my Lord.

div.head: Scene 6. Enter Melinet and du Prette his Man.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Hast thou been with my Lord Lotharicus?

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and he bid me return his service, and tell you he will not stir abroad, in expectation of your company; but he prays it may be before the hour of his usual visits.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Well, leave me.

div.l: Alas my Lord! I must prevent those visits:
The ruine of your Love must lay the strong
Foundation to my lasting Greatness.
In which design, if that my plot does fail,
Farewel my puff of honor— for all actions,
The ne'er so well design'd by strength of reason,
And prosecuted by the faithfullest Love,
If unsuccesful, finds small acknowledgement.
div.p:
It is only being blest by Fortune in the end, that gives the intention value. That's the unjust scale, by which the world weighs all things. But why should I condemn ingratitude as Vice, that for ambition turn a Villain, and betray my friend? Yet 'tis not I am guilty, though I act the Crime; 'tis the abusive world which throws such heaps
of injuries and scorns on wanting Virtue, that mans courage cannot bear it; at least mine shall not, if a stretch'd Conscience will relieve me.
div.l: I'l grasp a fortune though I heav'n let go,
That I have heard of, but 'tis This I know.

div.head: Act II, Scene I.
div.stage: Enter Peregrine, Lucidore, Almeric and Valasco.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: When wilt thou grow tame, Lucidore?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: When Usurers commonly grow mad, when I have lost all my money, and that I am forc'd to think of Marriage for the convenient support of some rich widows Jointure, which very reflection should I continue in it but a quarter of an hour, it would make me look as serious as any English sanctified Brother, that intends the Reformation of Religion.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Are you so great a Woman-hater then?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No Sir, you mistake me: I am not an Enemy to the Sex, but to that ceremony; I would be a Ladies servant, but not her Prentice: I love not to seal words of Complement for term of life, as that of taking a woman for better for worse.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If living single were an argument of Understanding, we might justly be esteem'd one of the wisest Nations of the world; for most of our young Gallants decline Marriage, and take Mistresses, by which they gain diseases in their youth, to make a Wife necessary for a Nurse in their age: and things taken by way of necessity, can lay no charge upon us for defect of Reason.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Right, for it is then the offspring of it.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Well, could I have my wish, it should be to see Lucidore in Love.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, I am in Love, infinitely in Love, up to the head and ears in Love.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Sure thy Mistress is very kind then, thou art so merry.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: She is so, she denies me nothing that I ask her.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: She is very coming too it seems. Pr'ythee tell me, is she thy particular Mistress, or is she one that may be generally so to all thy Friends?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No Sir, I will assure you I am not so free to keep a communicative Mistress.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why, canst thou seriously love any thing?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, when the object's worthy; and I presume her infinitely so, her charms beget so many slaves.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I fain would see her: I dare be confident she will make none of me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nor of me.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: And I dare warrant you for my particular.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You are all fair promisers, Gentlemen; if you will lay a hundred Pistols a piece, or so, you shall see her: Nay more, I'l take your own words whether you love or not; you shall be the accusers of your own hearts, and then I'l be the Executioner of your Purses. This is fair play, here's no false Dice nor Cards, all's above board.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That's true, but you hold the sight too costly; you forget that we can see the Creation of the World for 18 pence, where there are twenty fine sights besides the Woman. A hundred Pistols to see a Woman! Why, it had been enough for Adam to have offer'd, when Eve was promised and not made.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, I percieve you have examin'd your Conscience, and find you are frail, and date not venture your Money, for all your boasting.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: But we will hazard our Liberties, and that's of greater value.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I, but I never lov'd to expose my friends to danger, unless some profit may accrew by it to them or me; and all from this will be the certain knowledg, that you know not your selves, and that's an Article of Faith I have already put into my Creed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But 'tis not in ours, and we would not have thee have the start of us in Faith and Works too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, I'l leave you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Faith thou shalt not, for we will go with thee and see thy Mistress.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, I will for this once save your longings: the name of a Mistress has so wound up your curiosities, that I find your tongues will be like the perpetual Motion in importunities, till that be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Shall we go with thee now, and see her?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, I am otherwise engag'd; to morrow I am at your service.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Remember your promise, and do not have us answer'd, you are from home, as Misers use to do to save their meat, when a friend bids himself to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, for there must be no Courtship you know, that's against the Laws of Friendship, to buy a bargain out of another mans hands.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You have often encouraged me to hope all proofs of your affection, and I cannot doubt your friendship.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: You need not, your own merits, and relation to Marcelia, has fetter'd me your servant; therefore command me without the introduction of a Complement.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Why then, my Lord, I know you have an interest in Arcasia, and I must beg you to make use of it to my assistance, for I confess my heart has found the power of her Charms.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: You need not blush to own them, she is an object worthy of your inclinations; and I am glad your choice directed you, where I may pay part of the obligations back I have so often owed unto your friendship: not but your own deserts will be your best Orators.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: My Lord, I know my self better, than to admit the least hope from those vain apprehensions: but being presented by you, the esteem she holds of your judgment will doubtless keep her, from searching too inquisitively into those defects, which might with justice blast my hopes.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: You are too eminently deserving for to need such an impostor help: but Melinet, be confident I will speak the truth, with all the earnestness a Friend can urge: to promise more were to exceed my power.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: If you could perswade her to the Gardens, you would have greater opportunity and more of time.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I will, and use all my interest.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Pray be secret in it.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: You need not fear, she has too many Pretenders that would becom concern'd.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I fear you not to any but Marcelia.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Well, be confident she shall not know it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Give me your hand and honor upon it.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: There 'tis, an Oath I never broke yet, and so farewell, for I must go and see her: your servant.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I would go too, but I saw her but last night, and she likes not my company, she will needs have it that I am melancholy grown.

div.head: Scene 3. Enter Graculus and a company of Beggar-boys.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p:
Come Boys, let me see you make your legs, whilst I have it in my head how it may be done: for I have bin at the Dancing-schole a purpose to learn my self,
that I might correct you upon knowledg. Come my brave Boys, the most mannerly shall have the best Livery. [The Boys put off their hats, and make several ridiculous Congies.] Excellent well done: I do not think ther's a parcel of better bred Boys in Town, considering their Qualities. Let me see you run Boys. [They run. Oh bravely done! they are so nimble of heel, they'l quickly run out of a Foot-body into a Gentleman of the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Would you would let us go Sir to the Dancing-School, that we might see the fashion of it; I warrant you we would observe, and have some of it away with us.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: These Rogues would watch their time, and be stealing: take heed of that Boys; at the end of that hangs a Halter: Never go beyond the Rules of Cheating, by that you will secure your Necks, and it will put a value on your Wit; it is a general quality, and much approv'd: He that has never made use of it, has never bin truly in the Fashion. Your Gentile Cheats, they go to Gaming-houses; your Complementing Cheats, frequent Ladies Lodgings; your Flattering Cheats, follow Courts; your Learned Cheats; the Barr; your Seditious Cheats, the Pulpit: And such Cheats as you and I may be, and I thank Mercury I am, Noble-mens-services, or the places about Fools, Prodigals, or allow'd of Mad-men, which is the same. But you must be secret, Boys; keep your tongues idle, and set your wits to work, and in a short time we will be our Masters Equals in Fortune, keep men our selves, and be company for the best.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What's that Fellow going to do with those Boys?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I warrant he is some Parish Officer, and is having them to some House of Correction.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I'le ask him. Prethee Friend, what dost thou intend to do with those Boys?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Perform one of the works of mercy on them; cloath the naked: put 'em into Liveries, and let 'em out like Hackney-Coaches. It will be no small conveniency to younger Brothers when they go a woing, to make themselves Fortunes among some of the She slender-wits, with full Purses, who are so taken with a Feather, Pages, and Footmen, that they had rather marry a man well attended, without either brain or money, then any one of more substance, and less shew.
I hope you are no Courtiers, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why prethee?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: For fear you should beg a Fine for my having the benefit of my brain for my Fortune, or get my design prohibited; but if you do, ther's thousands will curse you; who, according to their occasions, would be glad (I most heartily) to know where to encrease or lessen their Retinue, as their Purses would permit 'em, which is most commonly a young huffing Gallants very uncertain friend?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Do you hear this jearing Rascal?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: It was ever so; your ordinary Fellows have no Breeding; they'l throw out their jests at any time, let it light where it will, though their Crowns be crack'd for it: and though they be blunt Fellows, their words many times have sharp edges.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well, farewell Friend; if we are no Courtiers, one of us has bin a Souldier, and they ought by their Profession to be as good at begging.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p:
That's true, but they are not so successful; they commonly act like themselves bluntly, without consideration,
and are usually denied without much ceremony; therefore if one of you is still a Souldier, you might be heartily glad if the King could unanimate you▪ and set you up in his Armory, that when he had no Wars, you might have no wants.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Well, God a-mercy Tell-troth.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.l: Come Boys, I'le go case you first,
Then have you to my Lord in Whimsey.

div.head: Scene 4. Enter Melynet, and presently after a Page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir, here is a Letter my Lord Lotharicus sent when you were abroad.

sp.speaker: Mel.

body.p: — My Lord, I have perswaded your Fair Mistris to the Gardens this night; where, if you think fit, you may take the opportunity of discovering your Passion: if not, I will, according to my promise, be your faithful Advocate; and hope to place you in that esteem in her thoughts, as may give you what is but Justice, the Precedency of all the rest of your Rivals; which is a service passionately courted by

sp.l: And must be treacherously rewarded!
Base Fortune! that offers me no other ways to come to
Greatness, but by the paths of Infamy! But hold Honor,
forbear thy whispers in my Soul.
I'm too far gone, thou sound'st retreat too late,
And now, for Virtues pay, no more will wait.
I'le not rewards in th'other world expect,
And present benefits for hope neglect.
It is Ambition's Dictates I pursue,
And following them, I cannot stay with you:
Then toss my Soul no more in Tempests so,
Nor make my Conscience thus my Fortunes Foe.
Go, and in Princes minds take up thy Seat,
I'le not forget thee quite, when once I'm great.
sp.p: Marcelia, I am coming to throw such rage and jealousie into thy heart, as shall, like Lightning, consume thy love for thy Lotharicus; I'le raise a Tempest that shall destroy him, and give no warning by a Thunder-clap.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: Methinks this day has time much longer then usually they are; strangely long, to me at least it seems so: How ha's done to thee?

sp.speaker: Desha.
sp.p: As others, Madam; I have no cause to make me judge this days motion slower then the rest.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: No more have I.

sp.speaker: Desh.
sp.p: It would not seem so tedious then in passing. But Madam, I much wonder▪ My Lord Lotharicus has not bin here to day.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: Very well apply'd: but the hours took not their increase, I will assure you, from his absence; not but that his company would have made 'em much more pleasant I confess.

sp.speaker: Desh.
sp.p: And by consequence not so long.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: I wish my Cousin Melynet were here; and yet his conversation now is not very diverting: The flowing of his Fortune has given his Mirth an Ebb.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Madam, here is my Lord Melynet.

sp.speaker: Desh.
sp.p: Madam, you see your wishes has their grant, as soon as ask'd.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: Cousin, your servant: you were the last I was talking of, and sure I am you are the first I see.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p:
I dare not credit such a Complement; two such
Obligations are too eminently great at once, for any but Lotharicus.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: If you knew how unkind he has bin to day, you would not judge so.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Alas, I know.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I know not what I was about to say, my head's so full of business, one thought drives out another.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: Sure whatsoe're they are, they are but troublesome reflections; they have chang'd your humor strangely. But pray Cousin tell me, What is it that so much destroys the quiet of your mind, and makes you wear so sad a countenance? You need no: fear to trust me with a secret, though I am a Woman: My friendship cannot let me see you so much a stranger to your wonted temper, without desire to bear a part of your misfortune.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I do so little doubt your kindness, that I fear your love would make you take the greatest share; and that almost certain knowledge makes me keep it from you. But leave this discourse, Has not Lotharicus bin here to day?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: No Cousin; he has not bin so kind.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Not here to day! poor Cousin.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: What's the matter, dear Melynet, tell me; You look surpriz'd: is not Lotharicus well?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: Why did you sigh, and look so sad?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Sure you mistook: And if I did, it was only pitying your condition: I know the time must seem tedious when an expected Lover does not come: And if you please to make it less appear, we'l take a walk into the Gardens.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: I shall willingly accept that offer; for some Air, after so hot a day, will not appear unpleasant.

div.head: Scene 6. Enter Lotharicus and Arcasia, in a Garden.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Are you still resolv'd then to make all your servants equally unhappy Madam? Shall not he be bless'd to boast the glory of your favours?

sp.speaker: Arcas.
sp.p: I am so far, my Lord, from putting such a value on my weak Merits, that I conceive he would be most unfortunate that I should chuse; and therefore being so equally oblig'd to all for their esteem, I will never be so injuriously unjust to any.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I am sorry I must prove so unfortunate a Suppliant for one whom I so much esteem, and does so well deserve.

sp.speaker: Arcas.
sp.p: My Lord, I should but ill demonstrate the friendship that I have still profess'd to pay you, if my consent to your request should give you power to wrong your friend so far: You see I am too sollicitous to keep up your interest in all hearts, as well as mine, e're to consent to be the cause that you should justly forfeit it.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I'le stand the hazard, Madam, of all dangers in that kind; my fears are far greater from my unsuccessful suit; and therefore 'tis in vain to think to complement me out of my request: that Court-quality I am too well acquainted with, to be deceiv'd in Madam.

sp.speaker: Arcas.
sp.p:
I see, my Lord, our intentions want Interpreters, as well as Languages; they are so seldome undertood in their true meaning. But since you will force me in my own vindication to make good what I've said, I think you do not love your friend, or else you'd not prefer him where you have given such convincing proofs you did not like; for if you had, you would have doubtless ask'd the service for your self, as well as have bespoken it for another.— It takes; I could laugh extremly [aside.
to see how strangely I have surpriz'd him, and how seriously he is studying complementally to word a Tragical Denial to my Comical Affection.

I perceive, my Lord, you little thought to have found a Courtship where you came to make one; but persons of Merit are often subject to such accidents. I have heard some swear they have had a hundred of them in their days; nay some, more then Arithmetick could number: I hope your Conquest is not yet arriv'd to such a large accompt: You see, my Lord, how different our intentions are, I strive to gain you for my self, and you to win my for another.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I know, Madam, the greatness of your heart too well, to have the vanity to think you would throw away your favours on one, whose wants in all things worthy such a blessing, forbids his boldness to attempt to beg it.

sp.speaker: Arcas.
sp.p: My Lord, pray spare that confidence in your friend behalf, which for your self do so much decline: And to recompence that Obligation, I will no longer fright you with my pretended Passion: I am your friend in substance, your Lover but in Chimera: But I thought it Justice to deprive his heatr of quiet, that came to rob my Soul of Reason.

div.stage: [They walk up and down, and talk softly; he makes several bows and submissions to her.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: There's Lotharicus Cousin.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Where? Ha! Lotharicus, and she with him!

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: Who is it Cousin? do you know her?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No matter who she is, or whether she were at all.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: I am afraid, and yet I know not what I fear: I'le go meet her, and see who she is, see if I know her.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Her name's Arcasia; go not for the world; you are undone and if you do.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p:
Why, what secret does your Soul contain, by
which you judge I must be so unfortunate? I must and will go.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Pray stay, your Passion will betray too much Love, and make that prove his scorn, which once created all his happiness. Come, let us be gone.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: Cousin, you are unkind, to put my till-now setled joys upon the rack of so much fear: I cannot stir; I here shall fix like a cold Marble Statue.
See how he does his Adorations pay!
Thus, poor Marcelia, he did thee betray!
Methinks his Soul should shake to let Heaven see his Perjury: But Cousin, could you, as I am sure you did, know he was false, and keep me ignorant of his being so?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I must confess I did, and found it too weighty for my friendship to support, and thought your Love would prove less able.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: He then is false: unhappy knowledge, that comes so much too late, and yet so too too soon!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: If your Courage equal but your other Excellencies, and that you will command your Passion to obey your Reason, I will secure you a Revenge shall equal his High Perjury,
sp.l: And make him burst with rage, or else return,
And in the Hell of his past falshood burn.
sp.p: But you must never let him know that you do think him chang'd for then all that you act, he will suppose the violence of your Love, and prove his pleasure, not his torment. Befriend your Sexes Honor, and be not thought to whine, to love, and be despis'd: Scorn and neglect him, but give him not a reason why; you are sufficiently convinc'd within; you have a Cause, and need not justifie the Act by a Demonstration of it; that may Eclipse your Glory, and augment his Pride.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p:
Oh that my dear Brother Euryalus were return'd
from his Travels! But I have ever known you Master of so much Reason, that I can hope no better assistance In this Extreme, where I will act a part, Your friendship counsels, though it break my heart.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Come, let's be gone then, least we are discover'd.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: We need not: See, they are about to leave the Garden by the other gate. Oh my Lotharicus! But why do I say my Lotharicus?
sp.l: Th' art false Lotharicus,? and lost to me,
Unless these wash away thy Perjury.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Can you shed tears for one that you should hate? Such meanness shews you merit such a Fate.

Leave: you have made a Conquest much more glorious, the King adores you, whom if you ne're can love, will make you at least thus far fortunate, that your perfections will with greater splendour shine in the whole worlds Opinion. My advice is, that you use it to your own advantage, and either build your Fortune, or reduce your Servant; for if you fail in both, your judgment will be question'd.
sp.l: By favouring one, the other may repent;
And all I wish is but your high content.
If that your seeming change can't make him burn,
To build your greatness, all your Passions turn:
Command, as Sov'reign, him you would obey;
Make him your Slave, that did your Love betray.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I cannot promise I shall e're be free,
But I will colours wear of Victory;
And my sad thoughts dress up in such disguize,
As shall deceive the most informing eyes.
Thus I an inward Martyr must become,
And seem to triumph, when I'm most undone.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: In my mind, Graculus, I am most compleatly modified: All the rest of my Brother Gallants may keep their beds, or put on their riding suits to day; I shall not leave, I think, an eye of a Lady for one of them: I shall have a fling at all their hearts; I am arm'd from head to foot with such an assault of bravery, Graculus; some will be taken with the Graniture of my shoes, others with the silk of my Suit; some with my Band, others with my Perriwig will be lost in Love. The Widdow Perilla, and all.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: But the Devil a one with your person, I [aside dare swear.— But you have left out the wonderfull'st temptation of all, your Lordships Wisdom.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I had forgot it, it was quite out of my head, Graculus: if it had bin much in the mode, I should have remember'd it: but hang'▪ 'tis almost out of fashion: not one Gallant of a hundred makes any reckoning of it. To say the truth, Graculus, it may well be left off now, for it has bin in use ever since the creation by report.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: 'Tis very true in troth, and things of much greater value have bin laid aside for antiquity sake: for, for ought that I can find, it is all that can be alledg'd against Honesty, that it is old. But I hope there will be some Wardrobes made of these castaway cloaths of our Ancestors▪ that the next Age, if they like it better than ours does, they may bring it into use again: for they are now both asham'd to shew their faces.— But my Lord, you have forgot to buy a Sword.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: But I remember that it is unlawful to commit Murther, that's the reason, Graculus.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: The Reason, for what?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: For not laying out my money to no purpose, on a thing I shall never use.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: You know not what occasion may be offer'd.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I know the greatest that can be, shall be none to me: whem I'm resolv'd, I'm resolv'd. Besides, I have made a solemn Oath on my own part to that, never to break it; and that makes it a double obligation.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: You had as good put it to the hazard in the Natural way of breaking it, if an affront require it; for I doubt you'l hardly live without.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I'l warrant thee, Graculus, I'l come into no such Criminaries; I'l not fight for my Religion, I'l sooner leave it: nor for my Estate, I will sooner let it go. And if it were not High-Treason against the King, and hanging-Treason against my own Neck, I would tell thee what I would do for the King too.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Never fear my Lord; you know if you should come to be hang'd, the sooner it is done, the sooner you are out of the danger of attempting or receiving Manslaughter, or wilful Murther.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I well tell thee, for I cannot hold; why, Graculus, neither more nor less, then I will do for my Religion, and my Estate; that is as good as to say, and the very self-same thing that I have said, I will not fight: No, and if nothing else can serve turn, against the World, the Flesh, and the Devil, they shall even take their course with me Graculus.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: My Lord, here's all your Pages, Foot-men, Gentleman of the Horse, Secretary, Valet de Chambre, Steward, Butler; here's all your whole Family in view.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why, I did not bid thee take me any other servants but Foot-men.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p:
No more I have not, my Lord, but all these
several Officers are to be hatch'd out of these Eggs.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am much pleas'd: I'le go to a Play first, then to the Gardens, come home late, go to bed without a supper, for fear of being sick with a full stomack.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: But what shall the Boys and I do, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Do as I do▪ I'le have as much care of their healths, as of my own.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: So, very good; here's cloathing of the naked, and starving of the hungry: The last is to be put for a Spiritual Work of Mercy, for it has much of Air in it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I cannot see my way Graculus; I'le turn the hinder part of my head of hair before.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Hang these Perriwig makers, they have made the Bush so big, the Owl can't see through it.

div.head: Scene 8. Enter King and Lords.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: The King is strangely discomposed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I, and if I am not much mistaken, it is some Female Beauty causes his high distemper.

sp.speaker: Lucid.
sp.p: Well, if this be the effects of Love, I hope I shall never let my eyes sacrifice the contentment of my heart to any She alive.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Indeed when Women govern there, farther then in Complement, they strangely unhinge mens humors.

div.stage: (The King whispers Valasco. Valasco goes to them again.)

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It is his Majesties will that we should leave him: Only, if Melynet comes, that happy Favorite of Fortune, he is allow'd admittance.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Were Friendship half so diligent as Love's impationt, Melynet had e're this crown'd my desires with some assurance of success, or left me to the force of my Dispair; for hopes and fears are the Gonvulsions of the mind: Fantastick Fortune! that madest me both at once,
a King and Captive, fettering my heart when thou didst Crown my head.
sp.l: By Acts, like these, 'tis Love does make us know,
He in his Slaves does no distinction show.
When by a Sov'raigns right I Millions sway,
That makes me most a Womans Power obey.
I, that my Neighb'ring Kingdoms keep in fear,
Can nothing bring to daunt this passion here.
It braves my Courage, and my Honour too;
Oh Conquering Love, what is't thou canst not do!
Thou tumblest mighty Empires to the ground;
Nothing beyond thy Circulation's found.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Welcome my dearest Friend, beyond all wishes but Marcelia's Love.
sp.l: I dare not ask thee, yet I fain would know,
What I shall hear too soon, or else too slow.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Sure, Sir, my Looks does not a Sentence wear,
To give your wishes reason to dispair:
My Face would ill interpret (then) the joy
I have, and bring you, if it hopes destroy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Does my fair Mistris then my Love allow?
Tell me Melynet, tell me quickly how?
I am impatient; thou did'st never know
What Passion was, thy answer comes so slow.
Will she, for me, her lov'd Lotharicus quit?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Love is a Child; she'l rule it with her wit. I find Sir, nothing so powerful in her heart, to give your Majesties hopes discouragement: Something has lately hap'ned, by which Lotharicus has lost some ground in her affection; and that which makes me almost confident, Sir, of your success, is she seems much more to doubt the truth I tell her of your Love, then disapprove it; and where that is strongly urg'd, the Present never is unwelcome.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: 'Tis true: but their desires of taking in of heart proceeds not always from their Inclinations; it is the general humor of that Sex to glory in the number of their Sacrifices, yet hardly will allow in their whole lives to pay the interest of one Offering back.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Were they as cautious in their gifts of Love, as you conclude them, Sir, their Sex had ne're bin tax'd of so much Levity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My fears are only now, she will not change; and if she does, I then shall fear as much she'll change again.
How can he happy be, whose unkind Fate,
Gives in his grearest joy, a doubting State?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Never give way, Sir, to thoughts so injurious to your quiet; her Reason will soon shake off her Feverish Reliques of Affection to Lotharicus: they will perhaps some little time make a weak opposition; but the Antidote I have given her of your Majesties inclinations, will infallibly expel that poyson.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I'l go and visit her presently, Melynet, that from my own experimented hopes, as well as thine, I may secure my heart.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Sir, if I may without offense perswade your Maesty, defer it till the solemnity of your Birth-day's past: I then will bring her to the Court, and there the particular honor that your Majesty may do her by a publick Address, giving by that the Lawrel to her beauty from the other fair ones, will infinitely conduce unto the conquest. There is no surer way, than baiting of their pride to catch their hearts.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I will expect that seeming Age of time.
How I shall pass it, none but those can tell,
That heav'n has seen, and yet must stay in hell.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I must go look my longing Lords, and whet up their desires of seeing my Mistress, with a day or two's expectation longer, the sight will come too cheap else, and lessen their obligations, if I afford it at their first request.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh my Lord, you are well met: we were coming to you for performance of your promise: we could hold out no longer, you have raised our hopes to such a height of expectation.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: I' faith the fancy of her beauty does so hant our imaginations, we cannot sleep nor eat quietly for conceiting of her, what I dare swear shall never prove.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, conceit her what you please, you are not like to see her this two long days, and so farewel.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nay, we'l go with thee and hant thy ghost, till thou let'st us see the desired apparition.

div.head: Scene 2. Enter Lotharicus at one door, and Melinet at another.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I do not think but we were both of us upon one design, going in pursuit of one another.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You have reason to believe, my Lord, I carry a passion in my heart, sufficiently impatient till I know my doom, which you ere this had found the effect of, but that Marcelia has kept me some hours her Prisoner, to make me promise to carry her to Court.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I then perceive I am discarded from that service: and were you any but the person that you are, I should grow jealous of you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: To divert you from that humor, pray satisfie my wishes, how do you find Arcasia's inclinations? I durst not come my self, and stand the Sentence.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I cannot give you hopes as you deserve; her resolution seems at present to be fix'd still to be Mistress of her own freedom; She says, the service of no man living shall prevail to buy her out: I hope time may change her humor; Womens first resolutions seldome stand good in Law against their second thoughts: This for your satisfaction, you have no Rival that's more fortunate.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: If I must not possess her heart, I'le pleasure take at least to think no other does.
sp.l: And hope, while 'tis to an Election free,
Fortune at last may kindly give it me.

div.head: Scene 3. Enter Marcelia.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: How shall I force my self to shew disdain,
Since still, in spight of me, he here will raign?
Love will not quit this place to rage or scorn,
But keeps his Int'rest as the Eldest born.
Reason and Honor, whither are ye gone?
That I this Childish Passion find so strong.
Will you be slaves to Love? resign the Field?
So many Odds, and yet so poorly yield.
But 'tis not much our weak Sex should submit,
Since Man's couragious Soul can't Master it.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: My Lord Lotharicus is come, Madam.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Well.
He comes.

div.l: Grief now retire; act here thy Tragick part,
But do not make my eyes betray my heart.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: I'm come Marcelia.—

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: — Whither pray so fast?
They often fall that make too much of hast.—

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Has my forc'd absence made you angry grow?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: You do mistake; your coming makes me so.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Ha! what's this I hear! I know it cannot be,
Thou art not chang'd thus to thy self, nor me.
This coldness comes not, Dearest, from thy heart;
It is some pretty trick of Love and Art.
Yet sure you do not so my passion doubt,
You need to take these ways to find it out.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I scorn much Art, but I could rage express,
To see he'd fool me with a new Address.
Indeed I do not; and I must confess
With the same truth, my own is grown much less.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: I am surpriz'd; Can you unblushing say,
You have your Faith and Honor thrown away?
Come, come, no more; you'l make my fears, too strong:

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I care not what they are, so you'd be gone.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: What is't you mean, Marcelia? what to do?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: No more, nor less, but tell you what is true.
I'm chang'd: Is that so great a wonder grown?
There are examples from both Sexes known.
I wish you'd leave me now; I fain would be
From Conversation, as from Passion free.
This is no Complement I must confess:
But, without study, 'tis my humors dress.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Are you Marcelia that I did adore?
I may be gone, grief lets me say no more.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: He's gone, and does a seeming passion show,
Such as none hardly from a true can know.
It is no wonder Women ruin'd be,
If all can counterfeit as well as he.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: What new misfortune does your Soul oppress?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Lotharicus has bin here; you now may guess.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: For him still sad! Fie, fie, you are too blame,
To let your Love so much your courage shame.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: When Love and Reason has a War begun,
Grief can't be hid, until the Vict'ries won.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: If he were here, I'm sure he was so wise,
With his first flame, his fecond to disguize:
I know he with great oaths confirm'd his Passion,
He did not else dissemble well in fashion.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: He did as much as Love could make those do,
That found their Mistris false, when they were true.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: That sight, I hope, straight mov'd you to belief.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: It did not that, but it encreas'd my grief.
No, I have done, what I but ill could do,
I scorn'd him much, to keep my word with you.
I hope that time will make it natural grow;
Till then my heart will never quiet know.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No more, no more of these sad thoughts; I am come to beg a favor of you; it is to go to Court with me to night, and see the Mask; it will divert you much.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Such sights to sickned joys sorrows augment,
A Grave can only (now) give me content.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I must not, nor I will not be deny'd.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I'm by my promise, to your counsels ty'd.

div.head: Scene 4. Enter Moriphanus, Graculus, and Footmen.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: There's to be some doings to day at Court, 'tis the King Birth-day; Graculus, thee and I'le go see't.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: I wish we could, my Lord, but they'l not let us in.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Not let us in! that's a good one; not let us in!
sp.stage: Walks up and down, and looks upon himself, pulls out a great deal of money.
sp.p: Not let us in! what think'st thou, Graculus, will not good store of these tempt? Besides, I am as gallant as the proudest of them, and as impudent as the best: And I'le tell thee, Graculus, they shall not keep us out: I'le fill my Hat of these, and cry, Make room Courtiers.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: That, I confess, my Lord, will be an excellent Orator for us; it is the most taking Language to speak in to all persons; 'tis strangely intelligible!— But, my Lord, let you and I do a frolick for once: You are infinitely brave, and I am in my worst Cloaths, and for sport's sake, let us see which shall get in firft: Let me carry the full Exchequer in my pocket, and do you carry an Eloquent Oration, which shall be pick'd out for your purpose from some of Cicero's works.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Tell not me of works, as long as I carry a Key shall do the work for us both.

div.head: Scene 5. Enter Lotharicus.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: How weak is man, to place so much of his contentment in a Woman, whose change depends on their unconstant humors, not their Reason! Those joys must needs be still uncertain of which they are Foundations. Ha! now I think of it, Melynet told me she had ingag'd him to carry her to Court: Sure she does design some Conquest there; perhaps Ambition has supplanted Love. Oh Jealousie! thou Torturer of the heart! I find thou now begin'st to seize my Soul! I'le be there too—.

div.l: By strict observance I'le her thoughts discover;
See if I'm scorn'd in hopes of some new Lover.

div.head: Scene 6. Enter several Lords and Ladies, and take their Seats: Presently after the King, Lucidore, Perigrine, Almeric, and other Attendants. The King looks round, and bows to all the Ladies.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Look to your hearts, my Lords, to night; Love is resolv'd, I find, to set them all to work: He has sent so many Beauties hither, I fear I shall go off my self a Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: If you become ingag'd, Sir, 'tis all our duties to attend your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am gone already.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: How Lucidore? what's become of your Mistris?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Faith ev'n crouded up in a corner of my heart, out of civility to make these Ladies room.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Which is the Beauty that has charm'd thee, Lucidore?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Your Majesty would laugh, if I should tell you how that devillish little blind God has serv'd me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Prethee let me hear then.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, that the Ladies might not fall out about the Conquest, he has made me in Love with all; with every one: he has compounded their several Beauties, and given it me at once in a Pill.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: So many Ladies taken in Love-powder at once, I confess, is a good large proportion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: All my hopes is, they'l prove like Leaden Bullets, one make another pass.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Well, well, Lucidore; Cupid will find his time to make you love in earnest, grow tame, and melancholly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, he has a Mistris for all he talks thus madly, and has ingag'd that we shall see her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: He's mad indeed then

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Does your Majesty think that Love will bring me into my wits?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I think it can hardly put thee farther out.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, if he turns once a mender of Head-pieces, by my consent he shall be imploy'd first among Statesmen, that sit at the Stern in Government of Nations: As for my particular, I'le dispence with my own cure; till he has done his work in that kind; for the general good ought to be prefer'd before private interest.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: He has found him an imployment will hold him tack till the day of Judgment, without having any thing to do with private brains.

div.stage: The King talks to Almeric: Moriphanus knocks to get in, Valasco looks out, sees him, and turns to Lucidore.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O'my Conscience here is the supposed Lord at the door, we have heard so much talk of by his incomparable dress.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Prethee let him in, he'll make us very merry: It will be more divertisement to the King and Ladies, then the Masque.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But he has brought a whole Regiment of Footmen with him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Keep them out; but let him in prethee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And please your Majesty, here's a suppos'd Lord will make you laugh: He takes himself, I believe, for an Ambassador; he comes from Yellow-land, a Country adjacent to Green-land, I am confident by his dress.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I confess, if his in-side be like his King smiles. out, he will not be wanting to us for sport: I think you must attaque him Lucidore.

div.stage: Moriphanus looks much upon himself, and walks up towards Lucidore.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I see he'll begin with me first, and please your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I hear there is to be dancing here to night; so I was resolv'd to come and make one, with the rest of my fellow Noble-men.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You wrong your self, my Lord, if you think here's any one fit to be your fellow, you are not to be match'd in ne're a Court in Christendome.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, Sir, I came not with that intention; my heart is dispos'd of, and therefore you'l loose your labour, loose your labour in troth, to speak in the behalf of any of these Ladies, if they were in love to death with me; for all that I can do for them, after I have said, Dye they must, and dead they were, is, God have mercy of their Souls.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis a hard case for you all, Ladies; you hear the doleful answer before you ask the question. To Graculus. Pray what's your inexorable Lords name?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: He's of an antient Family, I assure you, Sir; he's ally'd to above three parts of the world; his name, Mor-if-an-ass, which is by interpretation, turning it backward,— If an Ass, there's more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am inform'd of your Pedigree, my Lord, by your man; I am acquainted with abundance of your house, I thank 'em, they have made me very merry.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I believe your Lordship, they'l let none be sad of their acquaintance; every one that comes into their companies, or mine, we look upon as one of us.

div.stage: Enter Melynet and Marcelia at one door, and Lotharicus at another privately. The King looks earnestly on Marcelia.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Melynet, you are a happy man; and will be no less envy'd, whose interest could bring so great a wonder to the Court to night, so daz'ling a Sun at mid-night.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: She will be much more envy'd Sir, and if she shine fo in your Sphear.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Bring here that conquering Beauty.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: I know the distance of a Subject, Sir, too well, proudly to take what I have so little Title to by Birth or Nature.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: By one 'tis lefs then you deserve; and you already have gain'd that interest here, Points to his heart. you easily may make the other undisputed too.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: Victories so much above belief, excuse those that your Majesty gives them to for your divertisement, from a Reply.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But you have no cause Madam, to plead that reason for your silence; you know your power too well, but you decline to own it from other Motives, which in your answer, possibly, would speak you cruel.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: I know none, Sir, shall ever keep me from, the due sense of what your Majesty is, and what I am; and if I both remember well, I hope my actions never shall offend my duty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: But if time, Marcelia, gives me no more of happiness then that, I shall be at as great a loss as now: Love does require to be answer'd with something of the same Species of its own.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: Who wants the one, Sir, in that measure as their condition and their obligations ought to have it, never pays the other well.

div.stage: The King talks to her softly, she smiles, and seems satisfied with what he says.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Come fair Marcelia, I wish it may prove worthy the honor of thy view.

div.stage: The King leads her off; all the rest of the Lords and Ladies follow.— Moriphanus catches one of the Ladies, and says:

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: By your leave, my Lady, I am resolv'd to lay hold of you for my share.

div.stage: (She laughs: He leads her out under the arm.
Lotharicus stays behind, and grows into a rage at the Kings Courting Marcelia.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Hell, and its Furies! Oh I must be gone!
My Rage will for my Reason prove too strong.
Woman! what art thou but mans tempting shame.
That did'st at first his soul with weakness stain:
And still that power keep, and still betray.
Oh that some Plague had took you all away!
False Sex! that neither truth nor love does know,
But what ambitious pride can overthrow.
Thou Storm of Jealousie, thy sury lay,
Or else my duty will be cast away.
Oh Love! how you those raging Billows rowl,
Which whirl-winds of dispair raise in my soul!
Hold, hold, Revenge! if thou the Vict'ry gain,
I shall my Honor with some Murther stain.
It is my King that does my Rival grow;
That Name is Sacred: Reason, keep it so
Cruel Marcelia! since thou false would'st prove,
Why did you place so high your change in Love?
Had any other rob'd me of my rest,
My Sword should search my quiet in his brest.
Hence, hence, false woman! thou'rt unworthy grown;
Still in this injur'd heart to keep thy Throne.
In vain, Lotharicus, thou hop'st relief,
Till death does give it, by the force of grief.

div.head: Scene 7. Enter Masquers, &c. The Masque ended.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: You are sad, Marcelia, you take no pleasure in these divertisements.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: I must confess, Sir, my humor was ever dull, unfit for mirth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: If you continue it, I shall become so too by Sympathy.

div.stage: Exeunt Omnes: The King leading out Marcelia.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: — My heart affords my soul no rest.
But I will leave the Kingdom, go and try,
Whether my Love will with her absence dye:
That is a cure in Infant Passions known;
But thine, Lotharicus, too strong is grown:
She in thy Soul her Empire will possess;
Not all thy Power can make her Power less.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: My Lord, I'm come as much oppress'd with trouble from my Friendship, as I am sure you must be from your Love, to see your self so wrong'd by an unconstant Woman.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Her injuries to me, will prove advantages to you; therefore you have no reason to share my grief, no more then I can take contentment in those joys her change may bring you, in the increasing favors of the King.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: My Soul is not so mean, to wish to build my rising Honor on my Friends misfortunes: No, Lotharicus, whatsoe're you think, my heart is generous enough to be content, that they should ebb to nothing, if that could bring Marcelia back to what she ought to be, and make you happy.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: No more, dear Melynet, you are too brave, and I too base to doubt thee: But I have receiv'd such wrongs from Love, as something may excuse my questioning of Friendship.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: It may, and justly does; you're wrong'd indeed; we both are injur'd; for she unworthily could find no other out, to make an instrument to your abuse, and her design, but me: I must be chose out that unhappy man to carry her to Court; as if she thought the trouble would not be great enough, unless she made your Friend to help it forward.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: No, it was not that; she did believe your power there would make her more regarded, that gave you the imployment.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Curse on the Cause, if her desires from that did find success; my power there made your affections ruine. What fatal minute was my unhappy interest born in! But I'le revenge my self; I'le set all the Engines in the Court to work, and blast her growing hopes of ever being a Queen: 'Tis those that puff her up to the contempt she does express of your affections.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Has she then boasted to you of her neglects?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I, and gloried in her Falshood; but I hope she shall be made repent from her lost expectations.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I must confess that would allay part of my misery, to see her unsuccessful in her ambitious wishes; the news of that would be acceptable when I am gone.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You gone! whither my Lord?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I do intend to leave the Kingdom with all the speed I can.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I cannot wish it; yet I must confess 'tis wisely done.
I must approve what I would fain prevent;
But I believe you'l then find most content.
And, may be, when she knows that you are gone,
Her pride may grow more weak, her love more strong.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p:
I know not that; but I must beg your pardon sor I must go and take some Order about my Journey: I will not now bid you my last Adieu; but when we meet
again, I then believe that we shall part for ever.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I shall be much deceiv'd else: All things happen as I could wish; Fortune has plotted for me.
She's a good Assistant where she is a Friend,
Fix her but constant stars until the end.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: My Lord, the King has sent for you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I'le go to him presently; but I must give thee instructions first concerning that I intrusted last night to thy fidelity: Lotharicus intends to travel speedily; make it thy business to know directly when he goes, and follow him; I'le furnish thee with moneys this night: Do it as soon as thou canst with any safety, thy reward shall wait thee: Be sure and speedy, and make thy Master thine for ever; and one more powerful then he to pay thy services.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: I want not courage, Sir; and for my Conscience, it reaches, I'le assure you, from one Pole to the other; he cannot travel out of the compass of it.

div.head: Scene 9. Enter Lucidore, Peregrine, and Valasco.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What ail'st thou to laugh so? To Lucidore.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To think how impatient you are to see one of the oldest Witches in the world: For, to deal ingenuously with you, my Mistris is neither better nor worse, but even so.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Why, thou hast not brought us hither to put such a trick upon us?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Put her upon you: As bad as she is, I love her too well, and have too much use for her my self, to complement you so far to make you any such offer.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p:
We shall without any opposition in our inclinations
leave you her possession: Were she blind, lame, deaf, or dumb, or any thing else but Old, 'twere tollerable: But Old do you say?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I, as the Creation almost.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why, certainly thou art turn'd Projector, and think'st to go to heaven with a new invention by the mortified way of sinning: you had e'en as good take the old Road, for the Devil will way-lay you in the journey; and where he sends a Post-boy for a Guide, the Passengers commonly lodge at his Inns.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What is she Old does he say? O most abominable, insupportable, intollerable, Old! Why art thou so mad in all things else, and so tame in the choice of thy Mistris? Old! Oh Time! what would women give they had you by the ears, to pull you back again!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: We may let that string alone; for there are some of our Sex would be bribing as deep as any of them for that benefit, for many reasons: First, because they would have the World a little like Heaven, by times going backward and forward, and by that means prevented of coming to an end. Secondly, from a just belief, that Ladies dout not of that in us, which we so much despise in them; they care not to marry Methusalem, no more then we do the Witch of Endor.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And yet, before any of your brains are worthy of the place of Privy-Councel, Old Age must have lent you some of his Experiments, as well as Nature Wit..

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Then thou took'st thy Mistris to fit thee for a Polititian?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If she live so long with me till I come to be made use of in that kind, I shall owe much to her power I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Prethee, for laughter-sake, let us see this Wonder-worker.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, keep your distance, and you shall.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Thou hast given us caution enough in her Character of Antiquity for that.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'le be hang'd if she be either Old, or Ugly; she might be her own Guardian then; he need not keep her under Lock and Key.

div.stage: The Scene opens, and there lies heaps of money up and down; and there stands five persons about the Table with bags in their hands, dress'd in Antick habit: (as others at the door) They come out and dance, and keep time with their Bags and Pockets.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What think you, Gentlemen, of her? There she is; and her Attendants: Her servants shall give you a Dance. They all laugh. The Dance ended.
You see this is the Mistris of my heart and pleasure; I purchase her by the sale of my Lands.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And yet I'le be hang'd if she does not run away from thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, I am of thy mind for that: But do you not all love her? Confess, confess.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: The truth of it is, we should all lye horribly if we did deny that; we all adore her, and are her most humble and faithful servants; for without her, there is no satisfaction in this World.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, nor hardly a place in the other World, in Hell or Heaven, but what she helps to purchase. You may send your Venture by her to which you please.

sp.speaker: Val,
sp.p: That's true Lucidore; but I believe thou only keep'st a Correspondence in the Lower Region.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I do so: It was always my Fortune to keep company with such as you are, all Merchants of that place: I do not think yet amongst us all, we have interest enough
to make one Bill of Exchange so good as to pass there.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: There's not one of a thousand that goes about to try till fifty or threescore, nor so much as think of it; the Seas are very rough thither, and troublesome.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I, hang't; and one shall be sure to be pleasure-sick all the way, and must be still taking of bitter Potions to expel the gross humors of our inclinations; not one Cordial allow'd of; live or die, sink or swim, not one satisfaction to be had till the Voyage is ended: I am not old enough yet to think of Fasting and Prayer,; when I have some years over my head, I shall begin to do as other Grave ones have done before me, leave those Vices that will no longer keep me company, and think of Heaven out of necessity.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nay, I dare swear, thou wilt not endeavour to go thither, till thou art a Criple both by diseases and time, if Death will let thee live so long.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I believe thou would'st be as glad as I, that thy life was Copy-hold-Land, that as one were out, thou mightest renew another.
sp.l: I hate such Fools, us cannot be content
With pleasures which that World to this hath lent.

div.trailer: The End of the third Act.

div.head: Act IV. Scene I.
div.stage: Enter Lotharicus passing one way, and Euryalus another.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Ha! my dearest Friend Lotharicus! what unexpected accident of Fortune has given me this happiness at Lyons?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Her most malicious one to me.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: How? Does our meeting, after so long an absence, prove so unwelcome? Time has a changing power over all things then I see.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Do not injure so much that friendship I have preserv'd so faithfully, and will continue to my Grave, that little time my griefs will let me live.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: I fear Marcelia's dead, and dare not ask: The sadness of thy look confirms it to me.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: She is indeed; and I, that Death no longer can out-live.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Poor Sister! Poor Marcelia!

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: You need not grieve, my Lord, she's only dead to me.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Can you believe I can be so insensible of loosing in a Sister, what you so much lament the loss of in a Mistris? If she had perfections that rendred her worthy of your sorrow, they have as just a claim to mine.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Oh, dear Euryalus, it is not the death she ows to Nature makes me sad; it is her death to me, and all the Vows she made me.

sp.speaker: Eury.
