sp.p: How? do you tell me she's unworthy grown; so lost to Virtue? Lotharicus, do not strain friendship up so high, by charging of my Blood with Crimes.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I give them not that name; but I, with joy, would empty all my veins, and let life out, so that my knowledge gave my words the Lye.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Grown false without a Cause?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I say not so; I will not make her Accusation more guilty then it is.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: I understand not this mysterious Language; if you have basely given her reason for to change, condemn not the effect of your own Act; but draw, and justifie your injuring me in her.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p:
She has a cause from her Ambition; but my
Love was never yet so Criminal to give her any: You are like to have the King your Brother; that will render you I suppose contented, though it make your friend still miserable.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: How, the King!

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Yes: I give not this account for fear of fighting; you know I dare, and can, defend my life, though now death would become so welcome, I should unwillingly resist it.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Ne're think a Crown can come in competition with my friendship; I love my Sov'reign as a Loyal Subject, will give my Life and Fortunes to preserve his Rights, and him: This is my duties Obligation: But I had rather give Marcelia to thy Arms, then see her plac'd upon his Throne; nor shall she sit there and triumph over thy injur'd joys.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I cannot wish, my generous friend, that you should make your sense of my unhappiness, an injury to your Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: I'le sink 'em all, but I'le restore thee to thy lost contentment. I'le teach her ignorant Soul, that Acts of Honor is the Noblest greatness: I had rather have her live in Fame for Virtue when she's dead, then in a Title.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Pray force not her inclinations: I had rather still be miserable, then make her so from your Power. Gifts of constraint, though in themselves the highest blessing, are burthensome: Her person, without her heart, can be no happiness; and both, I know you cannot give me the possession of.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: No more, my friend. How long do you intend to stay in these parts?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: But till to morrow: My thoughts are restless, and I follow them.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: How far do you intend to travel?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Till I arrive at my wish'd journeys end.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: What place is that?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: 'Tis Death, 'tis Death, my Friend: till then I'le rove about the World, and give my self no constant habitation.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: My Brother is come to Lyons, I hear; I will go write him word how false Lotharicus is proved. Go, send the Page where I bid you.

sp.speaker: Desha.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: What strange effects of Fortune do I prove!
How variously she in my life doth move!
A Prince so brave, and in his Power so great,
Forc'd to beg favors humbly at my feet:
She never for thy glory more could do,
Then she in that, Marcelia, did for you.
Pride could not raise, nor swell my hopes more high,
Then she has given me Power to satisfie:
Nor can she bring my heart to more distress,
Then she has done in all my happiness:
Then bribes me with a Crown to be content,
And makes Ambition prove Loves Monument.
But love, if true, did never Power know,
That greater, then it self, could ever grow;
But that of Heaven; when it within the Soul
Does monstrous prove, and Virtue would controul.
No, no, I still must love whilst I have breath;
Nothing can give my passion date, but death.
But that Lotharicus mayn't pleasure take,
To think that his doth sleep, and mine doth wake;
I'le force my courage, give me to thee King,
Though I shall be a heartless offering:
And on a Throne in secret mourn that Fare
Destroy'd his Love, and rais'd me to such State.
As Princes ought, I then will act my part,
Not make my face prospective to my heart;
Nor give the Kings contentment cause to doubt,
When his confin'd, my Love does wander out:
My griefs and passions all shall inward burn;
The brave, their bodies, makes their troubles Urn.

div.head: Scene 3. Enter Perilla and Arcasia.

sp.speaker: Arcas.
sp.p: This fine Evening, methinks, should fill the Garden full of company.

div.p: Ha! what have we here? A Knight of the Sun upon my life.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You are mistaken, he goes for an Outlandish Lord.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Prethee what's his name?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Moriphanus.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Oh, I know him now, at least in Character: he seeks to be your Servant.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: You are much deceiv'd, it is to be my Master: The first time of his Visit he speaks all Matrimony, and left the discourse of Love for the second Interview: Marriage is the Captain, I will assure you, of his discourse, and Love the Lievtenant.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p:
Nay, 'tis well if affection has any office in business of that kind; for there is nothing speaks a Gallant now so ill-bred, as Marrying and Loving both in a place. But prethee let's make towards him, for I long to be censuring your Servant: Perhaps I may find more Merit in him then report speaks, for that seldome knows any meanin
disparagement, or praise.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: If your curiosity be so great, you shall go by your self, for I'm resolv'd he shall not see me.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: If his company be so troublesome, the most certain way to be-rid of it, is to marry him; and at the present put on your Mask, and that will secure you: for I must go that way and meet him.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Prethee what's the matter you laugh so exceedingly?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: I am conceited you us'd your Servant very roughly when he waited on you last: Confess, did not you make your servants beat him?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why should you think so prethee?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: By the trimming of his Suit with that deep Blew and Black: upon my Conscience it is an Embleme of some favours of yours in that kind; for he looks like one that would be cudgell'd, put off his hat, and give thanks.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nay, for that matter, I dare swear for him, he would, as submissively as any man, take a beating, if any one would bestow the pains to give it him.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Well, I am most strangely taken with the Mounsieur, as I live; I'd give a hundred Pistols he were in love with me: My Doctor tells me I am going into a Consumption; but I dare swear his company but one two moneths would cure me. O most incomparable Don Quixot! what faces and postures he has!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Prethee let us go, thou hast laugh'd enough; and if thou hold'st thy humor any longer, thou wilt put me into the same vein, and that will make me be look'd on as a mad Widdow.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: The more mad, the more fashionable; as long as thou art sure thy Husband is safe enough, for ever coming back again to use thee worse by taking of it ill, thou need'st not care.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What would I give now that my Year of Mourning were as much worn out as my Melancholly?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Have I not seen you before, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: That Question you must answer your self; examine your memory, and give account to your knowledg: But if you have seen me before, and have forgot me, I shall take it inconceiveably ill, that you should have turn'd me out of your head as long as the room was empty.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What fine expressions these Ladies have for any thing they speak of, Graculus?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: O yes, my Lord, they are so us'd to good Language, they can call you a Fool in a Complement, and you shall be never the wiser for it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Not the wiser for it, sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: No, not one jot I'faith.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Do you remember as yet?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, upon my Honor, I can't call to mind neither your face, nor hers in the Mask.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Then your Lordship knows a face no better in a Vizard, then out of it. Are you not acquainted with out names neither?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, I swear upon the Title of a Lord: But pray Ladies, do me that high favour to tell me what I may call you.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Why, we will give you leave to be our God-father; call us what you please; but we dare not trust you with our Names, you are so great a Gallant: Shall we Perilla?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What is she my dearly beloved Mistris Perilla?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: I thought as much; no sooner know her name, but taking away her reputation: You are gotten into the perfect Road of the Town I see.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I am Perilla, since I am discover'd, but not your Mistris.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: By my Honor, I'le swear before all the Judges in the Kingdome, you are, and shall be.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What, whether I will or no? Pray how many Mistrises more has your deserving Lordship?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Not in possession, but in report; for a right Gallant never keeps account in that kind upon truth, but as his humor serves him for boasting, and his memory to repeat over a good long Catalogue of Ladies names.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Be sure to reckon, my Lord, that none of the rest of the Modes of the Town may give in a larger Bill of Ladies favors; for if you do, you are lost if you think of Marriage with her; for she has sworn whosoever she makes her Husband, shall have bin as much, if not more, the Favorite of her Sex, then any.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why, I can be as much as the best then in their esteem.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: Can be? that's not enough, there's no glory to be had in that by talking upon supposition: You must say you have bin.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, you will not confess then how many Mistrisses you have had, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: If you examine me upon Oath, I must; for my Conscience is very tender.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Upon Oath? you may be confident I do.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why then truly I must needs say, I have had all the Ladies almost in the Suburbs, and City, from the Bib to the Furr'd Gown, lay aside all thoughts of their Honor and Virtue for my sake.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, your Lordship has gained much upon my affection, by this acknowledgment of the general favor you have had amongst us: I'le have your Mistrisses poll'd, and if no young Blade bring me a larger Bill of Fare out of the Country, 'tis ten to one but you shall know my mind in a week or two.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That's the Widdow I told thee of; Moriphanus is her Servant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He shall be hang'd before he shall have her; I could almost love her enough to Marry her my self.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nay, she's very rich too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Double temptations! I am resolv'd I'le get acquainted with her; and if she and I can agree, 'tis odds but I shall have a sting at Matrimony before I die.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, Arcasia, let us leave the Garden now, the Air is sharp, and if I stay longer, I am afraid my Love will catch cold.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: What, when the Fire's by?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: It cannot indeed, Madam; if you mean me, I'le stay as long as you please.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I wont venture it longer; I find it not well already.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes, praeter Lucid. and Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, Peregrine, let us follow that day-star.

div.head: Scene 4. Enter Du-Prette and 3 Villains.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: I am mad that Philampras is not to be found.

sp.speaker: 1 Vill.
sp.p: Why, you know it was not to be done till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: That's true; but the wind may serve before that time, and then he's gone: Now we may be sure of him; he must come this way from the place he sups. Be sure that you dispatch him.

sp.speaker: 2 Vill.
sp.p: Fear not; we'll make him safe enough for ever rising in judgment against you in this world, what e're he does in the next.

div.stage: Enter Lotharicus, and two lighting him with Torches.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: Here he comes.

div.stage: The Villains assault him, and the men with Torches run away: Lotharicus draws to defend himself.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I would willingly die, but not by the hands of Villains.

div.stage: He fights bravely, kills one of the Villains; they wound him in many places, and he falls.

sp.speaker: 3 Vill.
sp.p: He's gone to Heaven or Hell, and has took one of us with him for his Attendance.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: Are you sure he's dead?

sp.speaker: 3. Vill.
sp.p: I, sure enough, unless he has more lives then one.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: For fear he should not, I'le give him my last blessing.

sp.speaker: 1 Vill.
sp.p: Hold; he's dead I'le warrant (Pulls out a Pistol. you; and the noise of that going off, will bring in company, and betray us: If you are not satisfied, we'll open two or three Casements more to let his Soul pass out by; but 'tis unnecessary.

sp.speaker: Hark;
sp.p: I hear a noise; let's fly; we shall be taken.

div.stage: (They go back to wound him again, and hear a noise.

sp.speaker: 3 Vill.
sp.p: What shall we do with our dead companion?

sp.speaker: 1 Vill.
sp.p: Leave him, he is not known here.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes. Enter Meraspas and Philampras, and two other men with Torches.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Pray let us make all the hast we can: I have bin all this Evening to find you or your Lord out.

sp.speaker: Meras.
sp.p: Had not your business bin of such high importance to my Lord, as you say, I would have borrow'd an hours time longer to have drank with my friends here.

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Another time will do as well: we will go with you as far as the house, and there take our leaves; to morrow we'll meet again.

sp.speaker: Meras.
sp.p: I wonder what it is a clock?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Between eleven and twelve.

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: What's that lies yonder?

sp.speaker: 1 Man.
sp.p: Ha! a Gentleman kill'd.

sp.speaker: Meras.
sp.p: Heaven bless my Lord. (Goes to him and looks. O, it is my Lord! It is my Lord that's murthered! Oh cursed Villains that have done this, and cursed I that was not with him to have hope to defend his life, or lost my own in endeavouring of it! What shall I do?

sp.speaker: 2 Man.
sp.p: There is no remedy now, poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Meras.
sp.p: Pray help me take up his Body, and carry it home.

div.stage: (Exeunt with Body of Lotharicus. Scene changes to a Garden.

div.head: Scene 5. Enter Calinda and Ericina.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.p: Are you resolv'd still to give up your self to so much sadness? Is it so great a wonder to find men false, that you no better are prepar'd, from reasonable expectation, to meet this change and common trouble?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: It is true, Ericina, our afflictions do usually receive abatement from not being single Sufferers; but love admits not of allays, like other ills; nor is that humor (in my mind) so generally to be boasted of: Besides, Love, when it first takes Possession of our hearts, deprives us of our Reason; and that's the chief resisting strength, by which we opposition make against all other accidents of Fortunes malice.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.p:
I cannot think a Passion by Gods and Men so Deified, can carry in it so much destructive danger; for if it robs our Souls of Reason, it makes us like to Beasts: And certainly Heaven ne're design'd that Metamorphosis, from whence we have receiv'd the highest proof of that All-conquering Passion: Besides, some with their Reason make their Choice, and what it does approve, it may
subsist with, or banish it, if it too far intrude: That Reason is very weak and sluggish, that suffers and Passion to grow so strong as to supplant it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.p: I do not wish thee so much ill as 'tis unhappily to Love, or else I should be glad to see how you would rule your inclinations, which I confess you mannage well in supposition.
sp.l: — Would mine were governed by fancy too;
I, Player-like, could raign as well as you.
We can, unmov'd, hear others sufferings tell,
Which, if our own, we should not bear it well.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: You can no trouble have but what is mine;
My love does make my share as great as thine.
Unkind Calinda, what is't you intend?
To punish your false Lover in your Friend.
Can his inconstancy make you despise,
That friendship which you once so much did prize?
If you so great injustice will allow,
Ne're censure him; he did not break his Vow:
And who the self-same Errors will commit,
In prudence ought in others pardon it.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: You of injustice talk, whilst only I
Find from you both so much you fain would die.
Friendship and Love to me are cruel grown;
I wish to Heav'n that I had neither known.
Were yours true, you would not mine suspect,
Our doubt grows strongest from our own defect.
You on my Love a blemish fain would throw,
That in your change you might less guilty show.
Those that are wise do setting Suns forsake,
And with the rising ones their friendships make.
You know who 'tis has set his heart on fire;
Improve your int'rest e're the flame expire.
Love that plays Truant once without a cause,
Will still an Out-law be to Honor's Laws:
And days, whose mornings do appear most bright,
Are often over-cast before 'tis night.
If she his seeming passion entertain,
His half-made vows will cost his eyes some rain.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: She cannot greater show'rs for Love let fall,
Then I shall do for friendships Funeral.
Calinda, by my death you soon will know,
Whither to that I have bin true or no:
Then I am sure that you will grow more just,
And shed some tears for your unkind mistrust.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: If that can cure thy griefs my doubts have bred,
I'le make my eyes another Deluge shed,
Dear Ericina, can y' a pardon give,
To an offence makes me unfit to live?

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: I can forgive much more then you can do:
Love, in that kind, ne're yet a limit knew.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I grieve to think I should a debt contract,
Of which I cannot pay the Int'rest back.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: And I am sad to see your heart possest
Still with that Love, which gives your thoughts no rest.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Thy charming voice would make them calmer grow.

sp.speaker: Eric.
sp.l: I'd sing, and ne're give off, if I thought so.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Sing then that Song my humor suits and mind,
I'le sit down here, if thou wilt be so kind.

div.stage: She sits down, and leans melancholly upon her arm.

sp.speaker: Eric.

lg.l: Oh, you powerful Gods, if I must be,
An injur'd Off'ring to Love's Deity,
Grant my revenge, this Plague on men,
That Women ne're may love agen:
Then I'le with joy submit unto my Fate,
Which by your Justice gives their Empire date.
Who most is pleas'd when he can most destroy:
O! let the World no longer govern'd be.
By such a Blind and Childish Deity;
For if you Gods be in your Power severe,
We shall adore you not from love, but fear.
But if you'l his Divinity maintain
O're men, false men, confine his ●o●●'ring raign;
And when their Hearts Love's greatest torments prove,
Let that not pity, but our laughter move.
Thus scorn'd and lost to all their wishes aim,
Let Rage, Despair, and Death, then end their flame.

sp.p: 'Tis very late, my dear Calinda, and we had best be gone.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: It may be so, for time does slowly pass,
That runs by high Afflictions Hour-glass.

div.head: Scene 6. Enter Euryalus reading a Letter.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: It thou had'st such reason for thy change, I do not blame thee then, Marcelia; I would I had receiv'd thy Letter sooner, e're Lotharicus and I had parted, I would have justified thou Nobly did'st to slight him, and entertain the Kings Address, since he so basely left thee for another; nor shall he scape the punishment of his Perjuries, for I will follow him to give him death.

div.stage: Enter Du-Prette, and two Villains fighting.

sp.speaker: 1. Vill.
sp.p: Did'st thou think to make us do thy work, and cheat us of our wages? we pursu'd thee hither to Lyons to give thee death for thy deceit.

div.stage: Enter Euryalus passing, and two Footmen.

sp.speaker: Du-Fr.
sp.l: Oh Lotharicus, Lotharicus! thy murder is reveng'd. Oh Heaven! how constantly you still pursue.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: Ha! what art thou that talk'st of Lotharicus murder? Tell me, or I will take that remnant of thy life away, and by thy words, host that black guilt upon it? Speak quickly.

sp.speaker: Du-Pr.
sp.p: Sit, 'tis not the threat of Death can force me to confess. since I shall make my life, by doing it, a forfeiture to Justice: But from repentance and remorse I tell— my name's Du-Prette, and I know you to be my Lord Euryalus: I'le say no more whilst Witnesses are by; now take my life, and if you think it fit; or if you let me longer live, I will inform you all I know; that which shall give your Courage and your Sword new edge, and Noble work.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: Help carry him off.

div.stage: (The Footmen take him up. Look that thou dost, as promis'd, then discover; I'le spare one Villain to betray another.

div.head: Scene 7. Enter Lucidore and Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That little Trumpeter, Cupid, has so perpetually sounded in my thoughts the Widdows Perfoctions; her Wit, her Beauty, and her Wealth, as he has caus'd an uproar in my heart, and some of my own Subjects has listed themselves Souldiers under her Command.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Which prethee are turn'd Rebels?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
My Will, my Inclinations, my Covetousness, and my Vanity, to take her from the rest of my Servants; and they so stoutly fight my former resolutions, and my reason, that, hang me, I believe they'l get the day, and tumble me head-long into a Married Life, and make me grow
grey, and grave, with a Whither-go-ye, squalling Kitlings, and Curtain Lectures.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Certainly thou art a strange lover of Hell, that thou wilt be running into it before thy time.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, you mistake; Marriage is a preparative for another place, both by the mortification of it, and the honesty.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your Rival has bin to see the Widdow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'le Rival his Coxcomb if he comes any more there. Do you hear Sir?— (Turns to Moriphanus. I am inform'd you are the Widdow Perilla's servant.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I scorn your words; I her servant! I'd have you to know I think to make her my Wife, and she thinks to make me her Husband. I her servant!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, whatsoe're she thinks, you had best think of her no more, or win her now by your Sword.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Win her? did not I tell you just now, I have won her already? and I am not such a Fool to fight for any thing that's my own: Stake another Lady to her, and have at you who shall have both.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But then you shall fight.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Shall fight?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I shall fight, or be beaten.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Oh, I thought you had bin a man of that Authority, to have made me fight whither I would or no. I tell you then, Sir, I love her so well, I'd sooner be beaten for her sake, then fight for any woman in the world besides.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: This is a rare Coward; we'll have excellent sport with him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, you may take your own Election, either fight, be beaten, or forbear coming there.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since I may take my own choice, I'le take time to consider of it; I won't resolve on any thing too hastily.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: My Lord, you know your own certain mind already, and had as good tell it before you go.

div.stage: Moriphanus offers to go off, and Lucidore takes him by the sleeve.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, you are not like to stir till you have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why, Sir, then I will, because I don't much care if I do.
And now, Sir, I have consider'd of it, I'le neither sight nor be beaten for any woman, as long as there's God's plenty of them in the world. Here's a quarter and a do about a woman indeed!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why then you'l come no more there?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No that I won't: But what if she comes to me? I warrant you'l go and challenge her too, and fight with her: you think she's to be won by fighting; but, alas, you are deceiv'd, she is not to be won by the Blade; there's a Bill in the case which you know not of, which will prevail before the Sword.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But it shan't be long before I know the Bill, and the business.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: But what if I will not tell you? am I bound to tell you all that I know?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, not if you'l fight, but you must otherwise, I tell you that.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You should not need to press me thus to fight, had I not made a vow, the last man I kill'd in seven years, never to answer not make a challenge to any man living: no, you should have no cause to call upon me twice.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: To run away.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: You'd find I would not be abus'd. O that the time were expir'd! you put me into such a rage, that my passion must vent it self some way.

div.stage: Falls a crying, and turns to Grac.

sp.speaker: Graculus,
sp.p: did'st never hear that fighting was Physical?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Not I, upon my life, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why then if thou dar'st take my word for it, it is.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: But Sir, what makes you weep?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My vow, Graculus, my vow!

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your pretence of a vow, is but an excuse for your Cowardice.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Why, in troth, my Lord, if I were as you, I would fight, and for once break a vow made in cold blood, now your courage is so spur'd and chaf'd with these quarrolling Lords.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Let me see, let me see. Hum; no way (Studies. left to break this rotten Engagement, and fight?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, you may easily break it where 'tis rotten.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If you can find none in your Conscience, send but for half a dozen Advocates, give 'em double fees, and they'l find you one in theirs, and a point in Law to make it good.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: If it can be done by them; I'le make my own Conscience do't as well, and save me that charges: And suppose I am resolv'd to fight, there's more to be consider'd of then just that; there's time, weapon, and place.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That you shall have the liberty to Elect.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well then, let me consider; as to the time I can't do it this seven years, I am sure, I have business for every particular day; and if I appoint ten or twenty years hence, and am call'd to take my place of Honor in the other world before, then you'l say, I am not a man of my word; a Knave, a Cheat, a Rascal, or some such thing: Therefore it shall be a Duel in the other world.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: O brave, my Lord, that will do rarely: But who shall be your Seconds?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
Hold thy prating: I'le nominate my self who shall be both our Seconds: He shall have Alexander the
Great, and the Maid of Orleance, and I'le have Sampson, and William the Conquerour.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: I, my Lord, do so; stand to your hold; for you may lend Sampson, if you list, one of your Jaw-bones, and then he shall fight with Alexander the Great.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If you will fight, or dare fight, fight now for your Mistris: we'll find another quarrel to exercise your courage in th'other world.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I tell you I will not fight a stroak till the time appointed; so I may have some cowardly dog-trick or other put upon me: I'le have all that ever liv'd from the Creation, to that day, stand by when I Duel, to see that there is fair play. And so no more of that: I'm in great hast, and must leave your angry Honors.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I'le neither hold, nor stay: I am going to the Cutlers to bespeak weapons against the time appointed; and d'ye hear, be sure you meet me there.

div.head: Scene 8. Enter Melyent reading a Letter.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Lotharicus dead! thou hast bravely done,
And justly the reward of Death hast won;
Which thou shalt have; but e're thou com'st at it,
Thou must another Tragedy commit.
My Fortune now is almost made secure,
There is but one blow more it can endure:
Euryalus, thou must not live to be
An interposing Cloud 'twixt that and me:
For e're my greatness shall be so withstood,
I'le make my passage through a Sea of Blood.
My Soul is with too towring hopes possest,
To be by thoughts of Conscience now supprest:
Nor shall Euryalus prolong the date,
Which I have given for his dying Fate.

div.head: Scene 9. Enter Euryalus in disguize, and Desha.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: Pray go tell your Lady here is a Gentleman has business of importance with her, and desires to tell it her in private.

sp.speaker: Desh.
sp.p: I shall acquaint her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: All things are in this Kingdome as plentiful and prosperous, as if that none but Saints inhabited it.
But surely Sin's infection is grown high,
When Monarchs once their Souls with Murders Dye:
For they are Suns on which the Subjects gaze,
To gather rules for mannaging their ways.
How strictly then are they to Virtue ty'd,
Who, by Example, are a Nations Guide?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Oh, my dear Brother! dear Euryalus, how— He

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Thou'rt grown unworthy of such kindnesh now.
It is not love has brought me back, but hate.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Oh Heaven, what have I done to make you say't!

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: What have you not, could base and barb'rous be?
Murder Lotharicus, dishonour me.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I kill Lotharicus! Heaven knows that I,
False as he is, to save his life would die.
For worlds I would not live that grief to know.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: What Devil helps thee to dissemble so?
Has that black Favorite of Hell's design,
Taught thee this virtue with the rest to joyn?
Was't not enough you did his life betray,
To serve your pride made that be took away;
But with your curs'd malicious blasting breath,
Strive, in his Fame, to give him second death?
Or, did your Soul such sharp reprovements give
To your false heart, that fear'd to let him live?
Could bubling Greatness thy ambition swell
To such a height, to send thee Post to Hell.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I have no guilt, I hope, can bring me there,
But in my Grave you'l throw me by dispair;
For nothing's left to make me wish to stay,
If my Lotharicus be took away.
Where he in ashes is, I'd rather be,
Then here possess the whole worlds Monarchy.
Thy deadliest stroak thou now hast given, Fate;
Marcelia's strength cannot support the weight.
In life I nothing now but horrors see,
Since earth is rob'd (Lotharicus) of thee.
All it possess'd of great and brave, now lies
Gluttonous Death, thy malice Sacrifice:
Since thou his Noble life refus'd to spare,
No longer this unhappy one forbear.
I court thy cold imbraces to this breast,
For till my soul's with his, I ne're shall rest:
And sure it can't be long before it be,
Since grief and love both strive to set it free.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: What's this I see? certain I'm in a dream;
Falshood cannot pretend such high extream.
Marcelia, what to judge I do not know,
Since for his death you so much passion show.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Judge what you will, my Innocence you'l prove,
By that which quickly will your doubts remove.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Then 'tis that dev'lish Melynet has laid
That plot, which both his Love and Life betraid.
Treacherous Serpent! Monster of Mankind!
How could thy Noble Blood such tincture find?
Or thy false Soul permit thee to divide,
Two hearts which thou did'st find so strongly ty'd?
For he did for thy change such trouble show,
As nothing but the highest flame could know:
His daily wishes were, he might expire,
Because he had out-liv'd Marcelia's fire.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Add, add no more, least reason quit this place,
And after that, then this be left by Grace.
I am a Mortal, and no more can show
Of power, in my passons overthrow.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: To raise thy miseries I do not design.
But I would have thee th'top of Honor climb:
Refuse the King, then do thy Honor right,
To shew that greatness dazles not thy sight;
For his consent was given to the fact;
And marrying him thou wilt his guilt contract.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I'le sooner be to a dead body joyn'd,
Then ever in his guilty Arms confin'd:
No, no, Euryalus, his Crown can't take,
That Love away, his Virtues could not shake:
From one revenge I gave him my consent,
And from this second I'le his hopes prevent.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Dear, dear Marcelia, my most Noble part,
Thou mak'st me jealous of thy generous heart.
Lotharicus will surely in his Grave,
Rejoyce to see thou art so true and brave,
For Melynet, wh' has rais'd him self so great,
By strangling Virtue in it's proper Seat;
I'le trust this Arm to find me out the way,
The price of Murder in his heart to pay.
The King is by that awful name secute;
Subjects are bound what they do to endure.
Heav'n reserves it self the punishing them:
They are not here to give account to men.
Who strikes at them, Divinity gives a blow;
Whose Vice-Roys Monarchs all are here below.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: A very likely matter indeed, that she should refuse to marry me because I would not fight for her: No, no, she is not so ungodly, and loves me better then to desire I should venture my life: Besides, I never told her, or said such a word, that I would kill my self for her, or kill any man for her, nor go to the Devil for her; and thou mayst be sure she does not look that I should do more then my bargain.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: Why, my Lord, are you so ignorant, I mean unknowing, to set any bounds to your promise to a Mistris? Why, you should run full speed unto all you thought she would have, or could possibly desire, to make her think you were one mad, and dying for her; and when y' have won her, and are married, then you may do as most married men does, pace them in the performance, or quite bed-rid them; or if you will keep in the rank of the best Husbands, why then you must make your Wife Parson of your Courting, Vows, and Promises, and give her the Tyths; for when they have run out of their wits so far, that it cannot keep'em from going to Service, 'tis fit they know they have a Master.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Your Servant, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: No, Madam, I am not so happy to have it so yet. Was not that well answer'd, Graculus?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: It was answer'd like your self, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Do you observe, Arcasia? The veriest Fool that is can expect Government if he marries.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: And well they may: It is but reasonable, that those Fools that can get into that Authority, should govern those Fools that gave it. Don't you think it fit in judgment, that the least Fool should rule the greater?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I'le not speak my Opinion to the prejudice of my intention. But, my Lord, pray what gives me the honor of this early visit? for I had hardly din'd when you came.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I'le tell you a thing, but I would not have you trouble your self about it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Truly, that high affliction that put me into this habit, was so great, that it must be something extraordinary can move me now to any sense of sorrow.— But let me know it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I am very much afraid this will; and for all I came on purpose to tell it you, and 'tis very fit you should know it, yet you shall not know it, unless you swear, and give me your hand, you will not grieve about it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I cannot promise you it shall not trouble my heart, if it should concern you: but I will not make the least sigh of it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why that's it now; it does concern me.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Well, if it does concern you never so much, I will keep my word, since you have ingag'd me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Then to tell you the truth, the short and the long is, it was ten thousand to one you had never seen me again: I was set upon, and like to bin kill'd about you; my Man can tell here; I brought him on purpose to justifie it, if you should not believe it.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: In troth I cannot but be extremely merry to hear the danger is over. Lord, I do but think what a pickle I should have bin in, if I had known it when it was, by the joy I find now for the escape.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: He was in a pickle enough for himself and you too, I'le swear for him, Madam: the thoughts of never seeing you again wrought strangely upon him, to my knowledge, in that little time; that fear made him go lighter from the Gentlemen in personal weight, then he met them.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: It seems there was very fowl play; two against one.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, who were those Cowards?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: My Lord Lucidore, and Peregrine.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: 'Tis one of the humors, I ever knew, to forbid other Suitors, and not offer to come a woing himself.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Nay, I shall always be in danger of my life till we are married; every one will have a fling at it, thinking you love me best.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Alas, my Lord, I would not marry you now you have told me this, for all the world: for hitherto they have only intended to kill you, because as yet you have only intended to marry: but if you should marry in earnest, they'l kill you so too, for they'l grow desperate when they're out of all hopes: So I see plainly I shall be a Widdow presently; my Vail will be no sooner off, but on again; and to loose you so soon, would quite break my heart.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Truly I believe it would; for the thoughts of it almost breaks mine already.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nay, now I think of it, it was told for certain by my Nativity, that my second Husband should be kill'd.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: But are you to have no more?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: O, yes, yes!

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why then I'le be the third; I'le tarry with all my heart for you, till the danger be over, that is to come upon the second.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: There's a far worse, and more un-gentleman-like death threatens my third and fourth, then all the rest; for the one will be hang'd, and the other—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: What will become of him?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Why, without any ceremony, he is to hang himself.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: I had rather be him then any of the others, because I know mine own natural aversion against death, and should have this comfort, at least, that I should not be forc'd to die against my mind, as long as I was to be my own Executioner.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: That's a thing indeed, my Lord, would make the danger much less; but if I may advise you, run not the hazard, you know not what a good Wife may tempt you to.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I am resolv'd, I love him so well, he shall never while I live get my consent, to put him into the danger of it, nor my self into the possibility of so much grief.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Well, meer love of one another I see makes us both resolve never to marry together: Now there's not one of a hundred does so I believe:—
For all that, Graculus, I shall never put her out of my mind.

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: No, my Lord, if you stay here; no man can forget a dead Wife but by change of Air; therefore you must needs go and travel, to get you a fresh appetite to a new affection.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Will that do it, Graculus?

sp.speaker: Grac.
sp.p: I marry will it Sir, I warrant you; 'tis a receipt Probatum.—

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: 'Tis true as I tell thee; Peregrine is taken with Arcasia, and has made an invitation to thy Widdow, and her, to the Gardens; he intends to give them an entertainment there.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Prethee let us be his unbidden Guests for once, we'll not be in his debt, I am resolv'd I will send in my dish.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: A match, a match.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Lotharicus death, Sir, gives an absolute security to your love.—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: It does inlarge my hopes of having now the full possession of Marcelia's heart; but still a gallant man must be lamented; I, and my Kingdome both, may justly mourn his death.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No doubt, Sir, he does deserve it; and did not your Majesties concern ballance my sorrow, the loss of such a friend would cause much greater trouble in my Soul. But all things, Sir, does, and shall still give place unto my duty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I doubt thee not in any thing, my Melynet. But does Marcelia know yet of Lotharicus death?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: No, Sir; but intend she shall.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Prethee do; for I shall long to know how she does take it. 'Tis natural in Lovers to be curious in the search of that which gives them the highest troubles: and when there is a real wanting cause, our jealousies do commonly create us some suppositions; and mine does strongly work in doubts, for all her seeming kindnesses and promises, they're all but empty nothings to that passion her heart once had, and I fear still conceals for dead Lotharicus.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I cannot think it Sir: but I will soon inform my self, and give your Majesty satisfaction.

div.head: Scene 4. Enter Peregrine, Perilla, and Arcasia, in a Garden. A Table set out with several Meats and Wine: with Attendance.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: I could wish I had given my Lord Lucidore an invitation.

sp.speaker: Peril.
sp.p: I wish you had, for he is most excellent company.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And much your servant, I am sure, Madam; he is one of your secret Lovers that has not yet made discovery of his flame; but it will not be long before the fire break out, I am confident.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: I do not think he is constant enough, to think and say all at one time, he loves.

sp.speaker: Peril.
sp.p: Indeed, he does not seem to be of a humor, that his heart should be in any danger of ever being made a womans prisoner.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Would he were here to answer for himself: I could find of my heart to send one of my Boys to find him out.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: You'l put him upon 24 hours search then: When he goes out in a morning, by report, he is commonly lost all that day to any Enquirers. But perhaps his usual curiosity of seeing the Beauties, may bring him hither anone.

sp.speaker: Peril.
sp.p: Why, does he take such pains to be rid of his liberty, to come here to seek for a Conqueror?

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p:
No, Madam; it was his Opinion of his own invincible strength made him so bold to attempt the danger: He us'd to swear, as long as Cupid was a Child, he fear'd him not; he had not so poor a spirit to be worsted by a Boy: If he liv'd so long till he came to be a man, which he had bin these two thousand years a coming to,
and not one jot the forwarder yet, he would then stand upon his guard against him.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: My Lord Lucidore sent us hither to give your Lordship a new Lesson.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: I thank him; I wish his Lordship had come himself too.

div.stage: The Musick (espying the Boys coming at the other end of the Stage with a dish) begin to play.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Tis very hot, it burns my fingers; and 'tis very heavy too: we'll set it down and dance a little risk.

div.stage: Enter a Mercury with a great Chasi●-dish of Coals; reaches up the dish, sets it thereon.

sp.speaker: Mercury.
sp.p: Why, what have you done Boys? the dish is quite cold: you forget you carry'd your Lords Love, which is a Native of Freezland.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why, can it be cold already?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Cold already? I, hot and cold, and cold and hot, a hundred times over, to a hundred several Ladies.

div.stage: Takes up the Coals, and blows under it.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Pray stay a little, and we'll go fetch some Bellows, and make it boil.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Be quick.

div.stage: Enter presently again with two more Boys, each with Bellows. They dance with Mercury in the middle, with the dish and fire in his hand, every one by turns blowing under the Dish: The dance ended, Exeunt Boys. Mercury comes up with the dish to the Table.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: My Lord Lucidore presents this to you, Madam.

div.stage: Perilla opens the dish, there is the form of a Hart made with wings, in it a Copy of Verses directed to the Incomparable Widow. (They all laugh extremely.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: What is in it, Madam?

sp.speaker: Peril.
sp.p: Nothing but a copy of Verses.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: But I am much taken with the Case they came in; I have a great conceit all mens hearts are thus provided, they are so soon here, and there, and every where.

sp.speaker: Pereg.
sp.p: All mens are not, Madam; some are fix'd.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: That is then where the Ladies get to them by some more then common device, and clip their wings. But Perilla, the Verses▪ we will participate as far forth as the hearing the Courtship.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.l: Widdow, Faith I will tell thee true▪
My heart's inflam'd, and 'tis by you
But my passion will decay.
If you make too long delay.
Flames that with most vigor burn,
Soonest into ashes turn:
Then resolve, and quickly too,
Shall I stay, or bid adieu?
Foolish Lovers that do place
All their pleasures in one face;
Let them for favors long expect,
I soon will have, or soon neglect:
This is not common Courtships way▪
But since I lov'd you 'tis a day:
And if you cannot pay the score,
Y'are poor, and I will trust no more.
I've ways my Fortunes to undo▪
Without the help of lending you:
I can both drink, and game, and swear,
Does this not tempt you 〈◊〉 tell me fair.
Yet I'l a kinder Husband be,
Than those that sin more secretly.
But if you proudly now deny
To love me, Faith I will not dy.

div.stage: Enter Lucidore with Three Trumpeters, Almeric standing at a distance as not to be seen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sound a Charge.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: Why you make Love in open court, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I do so, Madam, to prevent the scandal of the world, which would go near else to say, I stole your consent, if you and I should marry.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: But why did you make your Trumpeters sound a Charge?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: It is the assault of my Love against your Liberty, unless you will come presently to party, and give me some hopes of an honorable peace betwixt us: nay, I have began my war in perfect form, I have sent two or three Heralds to proclaim it in the Market-place.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: Yet, for all that, you have not done like a fair Enemy, to surprize me without any knowledge of such an intention.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: All stratagems are allow'd of, Madam. Could you expect I would give you notice to fortific your self against my siege? Faith I'ad bin an ignorant Souldier then indeed.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: No, my Lord, she could not in justice; for if you had, she would have so strengthen'd her self with an Army of Reasons of her own and from her Friends, that her heart would have prov'd another Candy, impregnable.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: And quite tire out the Turkish Emperors Constancy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
But, I hope my fair Widow will not be so cruel to wrack my expectations so long; for if she should, I have no more to confess than I will confess now, that is, that I love her infinitely, passionately, unexpressibly, as much as ever any man did or will love any of the Sex: I do indeed, Dear Widow! but now if you should heep me in a great deal of pain by making a Chancery-suit of our Affections,
'tis ten to one but I shall rather deny all this truth again, than endure such an endless torment.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Faith, Widow, you must now resolve: this new fashion'd suiter will have his alms or his answer quickly.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.p: I, Madam, you must needs tell my Lord what you'l do, you don't know what an injury you may do him, by keeping him long in suspense; for if his heart should have taken post to any other place, how do you think his body should know where to find it?

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: We'l petition the King to introduce here the English Law, that is, if he loses it between sun and sun, the County must make it good.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: That is if it were stollen, Madam.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: Well, if it has run away, or lost it self, then he must have it cry'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Never think of these ways to baffle me out of my Heart, Madam, in plain terms you have stoln it; and if you stir out of this Garden without restitution, or my consent to keep it, hang me if I send not a Hue and Cry after you.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: It seems, my Lord, you are very sharp set to my Estate; if you possest that, I believe you would easily bequeath my person for a Legacy to my next Heir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Lord, Madam, that you should think so! As if a Rich Mistris were to be prefer'd before a Mistris Rich. Do you think I am so ill bred to displace your Title so, to put money before it? No, it shall never take the precedency. It is as much as I desire that I am certain it is one of your attendants: for where Marriage is made, and that a servant to neither party, there is always to be sure but beggarly house-keeping, and I love good company as my life.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p:
Well, I will not injure my wit so much to take seven years consideration to make up at last a bad bargain: as if a great deal of time were requisite to undo ones self
in, when a quarter of an hour will serve turn as well; and precipitated indiscretions always will admit of more excuse, than premeditated follies. This gives you nay consent so soon, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I care not from whence the line come, so long as it draws to my Center: I'l accept it good or bad, according to the old Rule of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: Well, once within this month we shall both repent it, after the Parson has ty'd us together.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: If we do, and the worst come to the worst, 'tis but one of us making a journey into the other world, and unmarrying our selves: and when it comes, we'l have fair play, draw who shall go.

sp.speaker: Perilla.
sp.p: A very just bargain.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Nothing will break your agreement then I see.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But first we'l try to break each others heart.

div.head: Scene 5. Enter Lotharicus in a Disguise.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: It is some pleasure since I could nor dy, at least to think that I shall now revenge my wrongs my self, on my intended Murtherer: and by giving him his merited Death, punish the false Marcelia too:
sp.l: And in the bud of her wish'd Queenships honor,
Nip her support, that treacherous Favorite from her.
She little think Lotharicus doth live,
So great a ruine to her hopes to give.
Here he must pass, and in this place I'l stay,
And make Death complement him in the way.

div.stage: Enter Melynet with two boys, Lotharicus meets him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Boys go where I bid you.— Ha! what's that comes there?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: An injur'd Lover brought by his despair.— Lotharicus.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: That's false I'm sure, I know thou sayst not true.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: His Ghost is rise to give thy crimes their due:
Villain! I live and with this sword will show,
In my revenge, whether't be true or no:
I all my wrongs upon thy heart will write.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: No more of words, but let us to't, and sight.
Boast not before we do the vict'ry try,
Perhaps it may prove your own lot to dy.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: I could have made my self of that secure,
But that my Courage Treach'ry can't endure.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I'l thank thy Courage and the debt will pay,
By taking thy unhappy life away.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Fall on then.
— Ha! methinks you back do start,
As if my kindness touch'd you to the heart.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: What it has done I soon will make thee find:
What think you now Sir, are you paid in kind?

div.stage: Enter Valasco, Peregrine, they draw and come between them.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Hold this is no good exercise.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: The best that can be, Sir, to us.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: How, Lotharicus!

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: The same, Sir.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: What wonder's this? and fighting with his so beloved friend my Lord Melynet?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: The wonder is far greater that occasion'd it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My Lord Melynet, I am glad we have prevented the hazard of your life to farther Revenge.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You have obstructed me in a Revenge, Which I could curse you for:— for by preventing Of his Death, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: We'l not take our leaves one of another, we shall have opportunity to meet in some other place.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I have not seen Melynet to day: I wonder much he is not come.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: Doubtless it will not be long before he does attend your Majesty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Have you not seen Melynet, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes, and it please your Majesty: I came from him: he is wounded.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How? by what means?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My Lord Lotharicus is return'd in disguise, and has set upon him as he was going to Marcelia.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Thou dost mistake, Lotharicus is dead I'l assure you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: And please your Majesty he has got such favor in the other world to come and live again; for I am sure it is not half an hour since Peregrine and I parted them.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Are you sure 'tis he?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As sure as my name is Valasco.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What should the meaning of this be? Go and cause him to be brought before me; I'l hear the motion of this bold attempt upon the life of Melynet my self. Are his wounds dangerous?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, Sir, very slight: they have both some little hurt.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Sure Lotharicus's jealousie has caus'd this quarrel with Melynet, because he knows I have a value for him, and by that concludes that he has injur'd him to Marcelia.

sp.speaker: Alm.
sp.p: And please your Majesty, Love from so strong an argument may be excus'd to grow suspicious.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p:
I am come to tell thee strange news, Marcelia; Lotharicus is alive in the Town: he has wounded Melynet,
and is a Prisoner for it by the Kings command, and is to be brought before him to the Court: the business is made very foul, as if he had surpriz'd him cowardly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What a compound of joy and sorrow have you given me? Poor Lotharicus! thou wilt find a cruel Judg: I fear they must, by heightning thy guilt, help to abate their own. I'l go to the Court my self: and hear his sentence, and share his sufferings, if my interest cannot take him off; I'l try my power first, then show my resolution.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: Thou mak'st a generous and brave Resolve, we both will go together: I'l there discover my self, and help to justifie my Friend, and if there be occasion against his guilty adversary. It will be time to go, Marcelia.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: My dear Lotharicus, thou now shalt find,
When most distrest, Marcelia is most kind.

div.head: Scene 8. Enter King, Melynet, and all the Lords, Guards and Attendants.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I am sorry having ever had so great an esteem of Lotharicus, he should give me cause to condemn him for his Rashness: but Reason is destroy'd in the wisest men, when passion does command.— Bring in Lotharicus.

div.stage: Enter Lotharicus with a Guard at one door, and Euryalus and Marcelia at another.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What makes me happy in thy presence now, Marcelia?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Though 'tis not fit▪ Sir, Women hither come:
Yet I most humbly beg to hear his doom.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Nothing's unfit Marcelia does desire,
Or of her King, or Servant can require.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: There stands my torture greater than I can
Receive from the command or power of man.
She comes to feast her pride, onely to see,
How much my Passion still does fetter me.
Inhumane Woman! lost to all that sense
Which thy soft Sex to suff'rers do dispense.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What was the cause Lotharicus, that arm'd your malice against the life of Melynet?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: My injurius, Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: In your opinion. Were every man a fitting and allow'd of Judg in's own cause, we need not then have Ministers of Justice.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: I question not the prudence of consider'd and allow'd of Laws, Sir; though now I sought not their assistance. But, Sir, in my own defence, I humbly do present your Majesty this Paper; which renders me incapable their benefit, and made me strive, by my own hand to take what I can never expect to have by any other means.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: How have you forfeited your right in that kind, more than your other fellow-subjects?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: You'l in that Paper find, Sir.

div.stage: The King reads and changes countenance, grows into fury: turns to Melynet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Traytor! what hast thou done? is this thy hand? is it? I know it is: wherewith th'hast set the feal of my dishonor; charge me with the consent of Murther, and mountain up my promises their recompence!— Here, Read it publickly; my brow wears not a guilt so dark to keep it in obscurity, although I ow that intended kindness to brave Lotharicus's Loyalty.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Du-Prette, be sure and speedy in the death of Lotharicus, the King is impatient till he hears it, he will double thy rewards I promised.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: There's enough.
How durst thou assume the injuring thy Soveraign so?

Though I Marcelia lov'd, I never did design to buy her favors at the price of all my Honors. By noble ways I bid
thee seek to gain me her affection, but not by guilt and treacherous baseness, Villain. The share thy veins has in her blood, gives thee thy life: but never after this day see thy incensed Monarch's face again! But how came you by this Letter, Lotharicus?

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.p: Sir, one Philampras, which was hir'd amongst others, by Du-prette, Melynet's man to assasin me understanding by Du-prette's Discourse that he had moneys in his Portmantue, watch'd his opportunity to take it aways and finding this Letter there, thought he should make more advantage by that from my Reward, that his promis'd recompence for my Murther: so left the money to prevent Duprette's sudden missing of his Paper; and coming with my man to discover it, found me as they then supposed kill'd; but after, on my Recovery, deliver'd it into my hands.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Oh! how seriously ought Princes first to weigh the lives and souls of men, before they draw them to their bosoms! for Favorites that are vitious, are the Cankers of Kings Courts, and eat in their Soveraigns bosoms.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Sir!—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hold, say no more, thy breath's infectious grown And on my Fame has Killing poyson thrown.
Guard, take him away.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Vain joys of mortal Life! you fly so fast,
Man hardly knows you are, before y' are past:
Yet we on you do our affections lay,
As if we here eternally should stay.
Honor, thou now dost give my soul a view
Of what I left when first I banish'd you.
O Virtue! how have I bin led astray.
From thy fair paths, into this Lab'rinth way?
I thought my Fortune on a Rock did stand.
But Guilts foundation still proves foolish sand.
When man by Crimes does plots for greatness lay,
Heav'n justly frowns and takes his hopes away.
But though my Life bears characters of shame:
My Death shall leave behind a better Fame.
They that won't fall, must not on danger stand;
We carry not our Fates in our own hand.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Though Love, Lotharicus, did make me be Thy Rival, I was ne'er thy Enemy:
At lest to take thy life by ways obscure,
My soul such abject thoughts scorn to endure.
To witness it, I this for thee will do:
Marcelia freely shall chuse me or you.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Marcelia, Sir, cannot disputethe choice:
Against my self your Goodness has my voice.
And she long since has learn'd to be so wise,
To leave Lotharicus for such a prize.
Pardon me, Sir, that I am sad, that she
Found not such motives for her love in me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I never more desir'd than what in you
I did enjoy, when I believ'd you true:
But when by Melynet I was inform'd,
I and my love was for Arcasia scorn'd:
I then such Reason had to entertain
So great a Monarch, and so high a Flame:
That all I for his Passion since did do,
Can no condemning censure find for you:
Honor and Virtue still have bin my guid,
My Life has strictly to their Rules bin ty'd.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Since Melynet made me so false appear,
You need not more your actions for to clear:
But still as they justly more splendid grow,
My heart does more despairing sorrow know.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Which of us two, Madam, shall happy be?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Heav'n leaves me not to an Election free.
Both so deserve, Sir, that If I should chuse,
I'd be unjust to him I did refuse.
Oh Gods! what punishment do you design
Marcelia, that neither must be mine!
Love will not let me my Lotharicus leave,
Nor Honor won't permit I him receive.

div.stage: [The King whispers to Peregrine▪ Exit Pereg.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To shew that I will still be here within,
What I am by my birth, my passions King:
My Empire there, by Reasons power maintain,
As well as to my Crown, new Crowns to gain:
I out of Honor will this Justice do,
Against my Love, Marcelia give to you▪
Thou art already of her Heart possest,
And with her Person now I'l make thee blest.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: Sir,—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No more oppose thy bliss with gen'rous strife,
May you be happy in each others life:
My heart to my Calinda I'l restore,
Whose due it was by faith and love before.

sp.speaker: Loth.
sp.l: May Fortune showr such Blessings on your head,
That over all the World your power be spread:
That every Monarch that enjoys a Throne,
May that possession from your bounty own.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.l: Now take the Blessing which I, Sir, do give,
When you are call'd from hence to Heav'n to live:
And may my Friend prove joys so high refin'd,
To equal the vast compass of his mind.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Sir, I am come my Duty to express.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To me Calinda can own nothing less;
In publick I my heart away did take▪
And I'l in publick Restitution make.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Your Will can strangely of your Heart dispose,
My Will, as yet, o'r mine no Empire knows.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yet it may yours perswade, and command mine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You should not then Marceliaes Love decline.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Madam, you have all Reason to express,
As much as you can say in scorns excess:
But Heav'n the greatest faults that are forgive,
'Tis noble, when we may kill, to let live.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Had you bin still, Sir, to that Maxim true,
I had not then bin scorn'd, nor left by you:
When you the life did take of all my joy,
You show'd not the left pity to destroy.
But you would have, I find, a Womans breast
With more Compassion and more Love possest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'd have thy Heart again thy Love renew,
Since mine does burn with a fresh Flame to you.
Calinda, with my Life I would redeem.
What I have done, to call back thy esteem.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Your Majesty can strangely overcome,
Scarce wish a Victory before 'tis won:
That price my Heart will never let you pay,
Love's Gen'ral there, and yields you up the day

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And if I e'er again that gift abuse,
May Heav'n all prayers that I make refuse:
I much admir'd thy Excellence heretofore;
But now Idolater shall turn, and thee adore.
I did not think this would have bin the close:
sp.q: Man may design, but Heav'n will still dispose.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: NOw I am sure, all look that I should say
Something like asking pardon for the Play:
With low submission, and I can't tell what:
Excuse her Writing, Language, and her Plot!
As crafty Poets Guilty cry their Wit,
To make you less severe in lashing it.
But, faith, she scorns such undermining ways,
Of blowing up your pity into praise;
Nor will she do her spirit so much wrong,
To beg what does not to her brow belong.
She says, they're fools force Fate, before they be
Resolv'd to meet with any Destiny.
But, this revenge she's sure to have on those,
They'l Cowards be esteem'd that give her blows.
Which strangely takes her! knowing that ye must
Be to your Honor, or your Wit unjust.
Mark how maliciously her snares sh'as laid:
Praise or Condemn, you're equally betray'd.
